{{Infobox cricketer | name = | fullname = Jason Anderson | nickname = | country = Bermuda | international = true | internationalspan = 2010–2013 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|2|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bermuda]] | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = | batting = Right-handed | bowling = | role = [[Wicket-keeper]] | family = | odidebutdate = | odidebutyear = | odidebutagainst = | odicap = | oneodi = | shirtnumber = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodiagainst = | odishirt = | club1 = | year1 = | clubnumber1 = | deliveries = balls | columns = 2 | column1 = [[List A cricket|LA]] | matches1 = 5 | runs1 = 176 | bat avg1 = 44.00 | 100s/50s1 = 1/0 | top score1 = 106[[not out|*]] | hidedeliveries = true | catches/stumpings1 = 4/1 | column2 = [[Twenty20 cricket|T20]] | matches2 = 9 | runs2 = 1 | bat avg2 = 0.33 | 100s/50s2 = 0/0 | top score2 = 1* | catches/stumpings2 = 2/1 | date = 19 February | year = 2012 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/362044.html Cricinfo }}
'''Jason Anderson''' (born 17 February 1979) is a former [[Bermuda|Bermudian]] cricketer. A right-handed [[wicket-keeper]]/[[batsman]], Anderson represented the [[Bermuda national cricket team|Bermudian national side]] between 2010 and 2013, most notably at the [[2011 ICC World Cricket League Division Two|2011 World Cricket League Division Two]] tournament and the [[2012 ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier|2012 World Twenty20 Qualifier]].
Having earlier played for [[Bermuda national under-19 cricket team|the national under-19 team]], Anderson made his senior debut for Bermuda in September 2010, at a cricket festival in Canada.<ref name="misc">[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/161/161401/Miscellaneous_Matches.html Miscellaneous matches played by Jason Anderson] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 22 September 2015.</ref> He went on to make his [[List A cricket|list-A]] debut in April 2011, against [[Papua New Guinea national cricket team|Papua New Guinea]] at the WCL Division Two tournament in the United Arab Emirates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/161/161401/List_A_Matches.html|title=List A Matches played by Jason Anderson|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref> Anderson finished the tournament with 176 runs from his five matches, made at an [[Batting average|average]] of 44.00, which was behind only [[Dion Stovell]] and [[Lionel Cann]] for Bermuda.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/14/ICC_World_Cricket_League_Division_Two_2011/Bermuda_Batting.html Batting and fielding for Bermuda], ICC World Cricket League Division Two 2011 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 22 September 2015.</ref> His highest score of the tournament was an innings of 106 [[not out]] against [[Hong Kong national cricket team|Hong Kong]], which earnt him the [[man of the match]] award.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/333/333423.html Bermuda v Hong Kong], ICC World Cricket League Division Two 2011 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 22 September 2015.</ref>
In March 2012, Anderson was selected as the only wicket-keeper in Bermuda's squad for the 2012 World Twenty20 Qualifier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/world-twenty20-qualifier-2012/content/story/553199.html|title=Hemp leads Bermuda at T20 {{sic|nolink=y|Qualifers|expected=Qualifiers}}|date=13 February 2012|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref> He went on to play every match of the tournament,<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/161/161401/Twenty20_Matches.html Twenty20 matches played by Jason Anderson] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 22 September 2015.</ref> but scored only a single run from his five innings, consequently finishing his [[Twenty20]] career with an average of only 0.33.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/161/161401/161401.html Jason Anderson] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 22 September 2015.</ref> Anderson's final international tournament was the [[2013 ICC World Cricket League Division Three|2013 WCL Division Three]] event, which Bermuda hosted.<ref name="misc"/> Aged 34 at the time of his last international, he continued to play club cricket for several more seasons, representing Cleveland County Cricket Club. However, in September 2015, Anderson was involved in an on-field altercation that resulted in him being banned for life from Bermudian cricket. Playing in a league final against Willow Cuts Cricket Club, he struck an opposing batsman, [[George O'Brien (cricketer)|George O'Brien]], in the head, which provoked a brawl featuring both teams and several spectators. The [[Bermuda Cricket Board]] subsequently found Anderson guilty of a level-four violation of the code of conduct for players, with a life ban being the consequence.<ref name="Ban">{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/bermuda/content/story/922573.html |title=Brawl in Bermuda club game leads to life ban |accessdate=22 September 2015 |work=ESPNCricinfo}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/362044.html Jason Anderson] at [[ESPNcricinfo]] *[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/161/161401/161401.html Jason Anderson] at CricketArchive
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderson, Jason}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bermudian cricketers]] [[Category:Bermudian wicket-keepers]] [[Category:Violence in sports]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jens Zimmermann | image = [[File:Jens Zimmermann Host.png|300px|Jens Zimmermann, the German Host, on duty at the sport event.]] | image_size = | caption = Jens Zimmermann on duty | birth_name = Jens Oliver Zimmermann | birth_date = {{birth date|1972|08|06}} | birth_place = [[Freudenstadt]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | other_names = | website = {{URL|http://www.moderation-zimmermann.de}} | signature = | module = {{ infobox sports announcer details | team = | genre = live commentary, hosting, on-site hosting | sport = [[football]], [[handball]], [[gymnastics]], [[wrestling]], [[ski jumping]], [[nordic combined]], [[biathlon]], [[Cross-country skiing|cross country]] }} }}
'''Jens Oliver Zimmermann''' (born 6 August 1972 in [[Freudenstadt]], [[Germany]]) is a German sport announcer, moderator and athletes manager. He had started his career as a press speaker of popular German football team [[Stuttgarter Kickers]]. Nowadays he executes announcing of sport competitions in Germany as well as abroad. Jens Zimmermann is the first and only German [[announcer]], who featured [[2010 Vancouver Olympic Games]] and [[2014 Sochi Olympic Games]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/23/sports/olympics/translating-the-thrills-of-cross-country-skiing.html?ref=sports&_r=1</ref>
==Life and career==
===Early career=== Starting his career in 1997 as a press speaker of [[Stuttgarter Kickers]], he developed his career to [[Managing Director]] at the same football club, where he held this position from 2009 until 2011. In 2011 he ran self-founded company ''"Marketing-Moderation Zimmermann"'', where he officially started the field of athlete management. In 2014, among the expansion of business, the new agency ''"24passion"'' is created. "24passion" executes the full-cycle Sport Production (audio-/visual support of the sport events), athlete management ([[Marcel Nguyen]], [[Frank Stäbler]], [[Anna Seidel (speed skater)|Anna Seidel]], [[Johannes Rydzek]], [[Manuel Faisst]], [[Andreas Toba]], [[Elisabeth Seitz]], [[Sebastian Bradatsch]], [[Luis Brethauer]], [[Daniel Bohnacker]], [[Aline Focken]] and the German handball players Felix Koenig and Marcel Schiller) and marketing solutions for business.<ref>http://24passion.de/#management</ref>
===Overall experience=== [[File:Jens Zimmermann by Olympics.png|right|thumb|300px|Jens Zimmermann at [[2014 Winter Olympic Games]].]] As the announcer Jens Zimmermann has announced more than 500 events overall in German as well as in English languages. His professional career includes sport world's top competitions like [[Olympic Games]], [[Four Hills Tournament]] in [[Oberstdorf]], [[FIS Ski-Flying World Championships|Nordic Ski World Championships]], Handball World Championships 2007, Mercedes-Benz Junior Football Cup (annually since 2001) and more than 60 handball games of German League.<ref>http://www.moderation-zimmermann.de/vita-11.html</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Jens Zimmermann (host)}} {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.moderation-zimmermann.de/ Jens Zimmermann's Official Website] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/23/sports/olympics/translating-the-thrills-of-cross-country-skiing.html?ref=sports&_r=0 New York Times: Translating Thrills on the Skiing Trails] * [http://www.stuttgarter-zeitung.de/inhalt.stz-interview-mit-jens-zimmermann-die-kickers-sind-mehr-als-ein-unternehmen.cb0c2284-7bbe-4cda-8d43-963bd52995e6.html/ Interview with Jens Zimmermann by Stuttgarter Zeitung Newspaper (in German)]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = John Dall | image = John Dall.jpg | caption = Dall in 1948 | birth_date = {{birth date|1920|5|26}}{{refn|name=birthyear|group=Note|While some sources cite Dall's year of birth as 1918, the date of 1920 is supported by the majority of sources, including published obituaries,<ref name=nyt /><ref name="tdt" /> ship manifests,<ref name="familysearch" /> and social security/death records.<ref name="Rootsweb">{{cite web|title=California Death Records|url=http://vitals.rootsweb.ancestry.com/ca/death/search.cgi|website=RootsWeb|quote=DALL, John ... Death Date 01/15/71 ... Age 50 yrs|accessdate=December 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101054826/http://vitals.rootsweb.ancestry.com/ca/death/search.cgi|archive-date=2012-01-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The ''John D. Thompson'' recorded in New York City's birth indexes as having been born in Manhattan on 26 May 1920<ref>{{cite web|title=New York, New York, Births, 1910-1965|url=https://www.ancestry.com/inst/discoveries/PfRecord?emailId=N-cc475129-9115-4439-ba3b-459943292c6b&collectionId=61457&recordId=239998&ahsht=2018-02-02T02:05:06&language=en-US&ahsh=c95695f7d2949c06a3fd74ec0b228385|publisher=New York City Department of Health|accessdate=2 February 2018|via=Ancestry.com}}</ref> is likely to be Dall. Dall's name does not appear alongside his parents and elder brother in the United States Census conducted in January 1920,<ref>{{cite web|title=United States Census, 1920|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/MJ1L-M6K|website=FamilySearch|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref> casting further doubt on a 1918 birthdate.}} | birthname = John Dall Thompson | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|1|15|1920|5|26}} | death_place = [[Beverly Hills, California]], U.S. | yearsactive = 1941–1965 | occupation = Actor }}
'''John Dall''' (May 26, 1920 – January 15, 1971)<ref name="nyt" />{{refn|name=birthyear|group=Note}} was an American actor.
Primarily a stage actor, he is best remembered today for two film roles: the cool-minded intellectual killer in [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s ''[[Rope (film)|Rope]]'' (1948), and the trigger-happy lead in the 1950 [[film noir]] ''[[Gun Crazy]]''. He also had a substantial role in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s'' [[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' (1960). He first came to fame as the young prodigy who comes alive under the tutelage of [[Bette Davis]] in ''[[The Corn Is Green (1945 film)|The Corn Is Green]]'' (1945), for which he was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]].
==Biography== ===Early life=== [[File:John Dall's Social Security application.jpg|thumb|Dall's Social Security application (1937)]] '''John Dall Thompson''' (he used his middle name for his acting career)<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|title=John Dall, 50, Oscar Nominee For 'Corn Is Green' Role, Dies|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A00E2D61F38E53BBC4052DFB766838A669EDE|accessdate=December 2, 2014|work=New York Times|date=January 18, 1971|quote=John Dall Thompson – he used the middle name for his career as an actor...}}</ref> was born in New York City on 26 May 1920,<ref name="familysearch">{{cite web|title=New York Passenger and Crew Lists, 1909, 1925–1957|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:24FD-1JQ|website=FamilySearch|accessdate=December 3, 2014|quote=John Dall Thompson ... Birth Year (Estimated): 1920}}</ref> the younger son of Charles Jenner Thompson (1873–1929)<ref>{{cite web|title=United States World War I Draft Registration Cards, 1917–1918|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:K6JW-P3Z|website=Family Search|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Jenner Thompson (1873–1929) |url=https://www.abmc.gov/node/555908 |website=American Battle Monuments Commission |accessdate=8 December 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6db48FVTj?url=https://www.abmc.gov/node/555908 |archivedate= 7 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and his wife Henry <!-- (sic) - yes, mother's name was Henry (see talk page) --> (''née'' Worthington).<ref name="tdt" /> (Sources which cite Dall's birth name as John ''Jenner'' Thompson and his birth year as 1918<ref name="kbh">{{cite book|last=Burroughs Hannsberry|first=Karen|title=Bad Boys: the Actors of Film Noir|publisher=McFarland|year=2003|page=176|isbn=0786414847}}</ref><ref name="Herrick">{{cite web|title=John Dall papers|url=http://catalog.oscars.org/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=65430|website=[[Margaret Herrick Library]]|publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.|accessdate=February 10, 2015}}</ref> appear to be in error.{{refn|name=birthyear|group=Note}}) His father was a civil engineer. His elder brother, Worthington Thompson, was later a decorated lieutenant in the [[517th Parachute Regimental Combat Team]].<ref name="astor">{{cite book|last1=Astor|first1=Gerald|title=Battling Buzzards: The Odyssey of the 517th Parachute Regimental Combat Team 1943-1945|date=2001|publisher=Random House|location=New York|isbn=0440236932|page=108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqKXqFfxVOMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA108#v=onepage&q=john%20dall|accessdate=December 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=MailCall No. 2210|url=http://www.517prct.org/mailcall/2210.pdf|website=517th Parachute Regimental Combat Team|accessdate=December 6, 2014|page=11|date=April 20, 2014}}</ref>
In the 1920s the Thompsons moved to Panama, where Charles worked on the construction of the airport there.<ref name="kbh" /> While in Panama, Dall was in a theatre when a cast member fell ill and Dall stepped in; this caused him to get the desire to act.<ref>JOHN DALL COLOR PORTRAIT IN PICTURE SECTION ''Chicago Daily Tribune'' (1923-1963); Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]09 June 1946: g9</ref> His father committed suicide in 1929,<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of the death of an American citizen (Charles Jenner Thompson)|url=http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?db=deathsamericancitizenabroad&gss=sfs28_ms_r_db&new=1&rank=1&gsfn=charles%20jenner&gsfn_x=1&gsln=thompson&gsln_x=1&msddy=1929&msddy_x=1&msdpn__ftp=Panama&msdpn=5177&msdpn_PInfo=3-%7c0%7c1652393%7c0%7c5177%7c0%7c0%7c0%7c0%7c0%7c0%7c&msdpn_x=1&msdpn__ftp_x=1&MSAV=1&uidh=000|website=Ancestry.com|publisher=American Consular Service|accessdate=25 November 2015|date=3 September 1929|quote=Suicide. Pistol shot.}} {{registration}}</ref> and his widow returned to New York City with John the following year.<ref name=familysearch />{{refn|name=panama|group=Note|Dall later claimed in media interviews to have acted on stage in Panama as a teenager with his parents in the audience,<ref name=cooke>{{cite journal|last1=Cooke|first1=Marion|title=Career Crasher|journal=Motion Picture Magazine|date=August 1945}}</ref> but sources indicate he had returned to the US at the age of 10.}}
John attended [[Horace Mann School]] and briefly enrolled at [[Columbia University]], where he intended to follow in his father's footsteps by studying engineering. Deciding that acting was his true vocation, he left Columbia and studied at the Theodora Irvine School of Theater and the [[Pasadena Playhouse]].<ref name="nyt" /><ref name="kbh" /> He also studied at the Petit Theatre in New Orleans.
===Theatre=== Dall spent six years acting in various stock companies, notably [[Clare Tree Major]]'s Children's Theatre. He also worked in companies headed by [[Aline MacMahon]], [[Arthur Byron]], [[Ruth Weston]] and [[Edith Atwater]].<ref name="dall">John Dall of 'Corn Is Green' By E.C. Sherburne. ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (1908–current file); Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass] 30 July 1945: 4.</ref>
Dall had small roles on Broadway during the 1941-42 season in ''R.U.R.'' and ''Janie''. In 1942-43 he played the lead of Quizz Martin in the touring company ''[[The Eve of St Mark]]''. He was well received and replaced [[William Prince (actor)|William Prince]] on Broadway so Prince could take a vacation.<ref>NEW LEADING MAN ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 28 May 1943: 18.</ref> His performance was spotted by Jack Warner's wife and resulted in a Warners screen test for Dall.<ref>John Dall, 50, Dies; Stage, Screen Actor ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 18 Jan 1971: 20.</ref> [[Warner Bros.]] offered him a contract but he would only take it if he could have time off to do a play.<ref>Before He Met 'Dear Ruth' ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (1908–current file); Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]05 Dec 1944: 5</ref> (Warners also signed Prince.<ref>Lamour, De Cordova 'Medal for Benny' Duo: Republic Announces Plans to Film 'Secrets of the New York Police' Schallert, Edwin. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 22 Oct 1943: 14.</ref>)
===''The Corn Is Green''=== Dall made his film debut in ''[[The Corn Is Green (1945 film)|The Corn Is Green]]'' (1945), under the direction of [[Irving Rapper]]. [[Richard Waring]] had been meant to play the part but had been called into the army.<ref>'THE CORN IS GREEN' ON WARNER'S LOT: Bette Davis Appears as Miss Moffat in Screen Version of the Popular Play By EZRA GOODMAN New York Times 30 July 1944: X3.</ref> The film was shot in the middle of 1944.<ref>Bette Davis in Barrymore Role in Film by Frank Daugherty Special to The Christian Science Monitor. ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (1908–current file); Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass] 28 July 1944: 4.</ref> Warners were impressed with the rushes and signed Dall to a new contract.<ref>Warner Bros. to Co-Star Reynolds and Hutton Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 Sep 1944: 15.</ref>
===''Dear Ruth''=== Dall returned to the stage to play the lead in [[Norman Krasna]]'s ''[[Dear Ruth]]'' (1944), under the direction of [[Moss Hart]]. It was a huge success.<ref>https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/dear-ruth-1607</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' said Dall gives "a graceful and easy performance".<ref>THE PLAY By LEWIS NICHOLS. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 14 Dec 1944: 29.</ref> Even before ''The Corn Is Green'' was released Warners announced Dall was one of six contractees they intended to build into a star (the others were [[Lauren Bacall]], [[Dane Clark]], [[Faye Emerson]], [[Robert Hutton]] and Prince.<ref>SCREEN NEWS: Robert Shayne Gets Lead in 'Three Strangers' Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 Jan 1945: 11</ref>)
After ''The Corn Is Green'' was released, Dall received an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor. He was called one of the "hottest finds" in Hollywood, and Warners tried to find a film for him and co-star [[Joan Lorring]].<ref>Special Story to Star Finds Lorring and Dall Schallert, Edwin. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]02 Apr 1945: A2.</ref>
The film rights to ''Dear Ruth'' were sold to Paramount who cast [[William Holden]] in the part originated by Dall. Warners brought the screen rights to John Patrick's play ''[[The Hasty Heart]]'' and announced Dall would play the role originated by [[Richard Basehart]].<ref>SCREEN NEWS: Warners Pay $100,000 Down for 'Hasty Heart' Joan Blondell Gets Top Part Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 19 Feb 1945: 21.</ref> Warners gave Dall three months leave to perform ''The Hasty Heart'' (1945) on stage on the road.<ref>Returning to Stage ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (1908–current file); Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]06 Aug 1945: 4.</ref><ref>ON THE AISLE: "The Hasty Heart" Popular Comedy with John Dall and Dort Clark Amusing in Leading Roles "THE HASTY HEART" Cassidy, Claudia. ''Chicago Daily Tribune'' (1923-1963); Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill] 25 Dec 1945: 23.</ref> However the film was not made for several more years by which time [[Richard Todd]] had been cast in the role.
In May 1946, Warners released Dall from his contract. He only made one film for the studio.<ref>PARAMOUNT BUYS HARVESTING STORY: Studio Will Produce Houston Branch's 'The Big Haircut' -- Lead to Alan Ladd, Special to THE ''New York Times'' (1923–current file) [New York, N.Y], May 11, 1946, p. 34.</ref>
===Universal=== Paramount announced they were interested in signing Dall and [[Edward G. Robinson]] for a role in an adaptation of ''The Wayfarers''.<ref>LITVAK, SAM WOOD IN PICTURE DEALS: Profit-Sharing Agreements Are Made With Enterprise and International Groups Of Local Origin Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 17 May 1946: 15.</ref> In May 1946 he signed a seven-year deal with [[David O. Selznick]]'s [[Vanguard Films]].<ref>Drama AND FILMS: Vanguard Signs Dall; Fonda Films Selected Schallert, Edwin. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 25 May 1946: 5.</ref><ref>MARLENE DIETRICH TO RESUME CAREER: She Will Return to Screen as Star of 'Golden Earrings'-- 'OSS' Opens at the Gotham Role for Humphrey Bogart Of Local Origin Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 25 May 1946: 21.</ref> Dall performed ''Hasty Heart'' in summer stock.<ref>Prospects for Autumn; Summer Playhouse Plans ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (1908–current file); Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass] 15 July 1946: 4.</ref>
Dall wound up making no films for Selznick. Instead he went over to Universal, where he signed a contract.<ref>Hedda Hopper LOOKING AT HOLLYWOOD ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]07 Jan 1947: A2.</ref> He played [[Deanna Durbin]]'s love interest in ''[[Something in the Wind]]'' (1947); the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described him as "ill at ease".<ref>Deanna's Her 'Old' Self in 'Something in Wind' Scheuer, Philip K. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]05 Sep 1947: A3.</ref> He was in ''[[Another Part of the Forest (film)|Another Part of the Forest]]'' (1948), based on the play by [[Lillian Hellman]].
===''Rope'' and ''Gun Crazy''=== [[Alfred Hitchcock]] cast Dall in ''[[Rope (film)|Rope]]'' (1948) as one of two killers (the other played by [[Farley Granger]]) who match wits with [[James Stewart]]. The film was not a big hit on release but its reputation has since grown.
After ''Rope'' it was reported he would make ''Shadow of Fear'' for [[Michael Curtiz]]<ref>Paul Douglas Likely 'Four Wives' Opus Star Schallert, Edwin. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 22 Apr 1948: 23.</ref> but this did not materialize.
Dall did "The Wind and the Rain" for ''[[Theatre Guild on the Air]]''<ref>'Wind And The Rain' On Theater Guild On Air ''Chicago Daily Tribune'' (1923-1963); Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill] 24 Oct 1948: n14. </ref> then returned to Broadway to appear in [[Daniel Taradash]]'s adaptation of [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]'s ''[[Red Gloves]]'' with [[Charles Boyer]], directed by [[Jed Harris]]. It was a minor hit.<ref>https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/red-gloves-2043</ref> [[Brooks Atkinson]] said Boyer and Dall's acting were the best thing about the production.<ref>SARTRE AND BOYER: ' Red Gloves' Adapted for Use in New York By BROOKS ATKINSON. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 12 Dec 1948: X3.</ref>
Dall made his TV debut in "[[Miracle in the Rain]]" for ''[[The Chevrolet Tele-Theatre]]'' in 1949. He appeared as one of the leads in ''[[Gun Crazy]]'' (1949), the other lead actor was [[Peggy Cummins]].
Dall had a supporting role in ''[[The Man Who Cheated Himself]]'' (1950). He was in the short-run revival of ''[[The Heiress]]'' (1950) on Broadway with [[Basil Rathbone]].<ref>https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/the-heiress-476327</ref><ref>AT THE THEATRE: 'The Heiress' Put On at the City Center as the Last Play of the Winter Season By BROOKS ATKINSON. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 Feb 1950: 43.</ref>
===Television=== In October 1950 Dall said that TV acting was better done by movie actors, who understood technique, than stage actors, who needed audience response.<ref>Dall Says Movie Actors Are Better Than Stage Stars as Television Performers Ames, Walter. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 15 Oct 1950: B6.</ref>
In late 1950, he appeared in ''The Man'' by [[Mel Dinelli]] on stage in Los Angeles with [[Gladys George]].<ref>Stars Chosen for 'The Man' ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 27 Nov 1950: C9.</ref> The ''Los Angeles Times'' said he played his role with "tremendous assurance".<ref>'The Man' Offers Faint Thrills at Las Palmas Schallert, Edwin. ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]06 Dec 1950: B11.</ref>
In stock he appeared in ''The Hasty Heart'' (1952), ''Gramercy Ghost'' (1952),<ref>WAGON' TO LEAVE SHUBERT TONIGHT: Loewe-Lerner Musical Play, Put on by Crawford, to Quit After 289 Performances By J. P. SHANLEY. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 19 July 1952: 8.</ref> ''The Moon is Blue'' (1953),<ref>STRAWHAT THEATRES LIST SUMMER PLANS ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 11 May 1953: 25.</ref> ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'', and ''Born Yesterday'' (1953).<ref>NEW PLAYWRIGHT ON SCENE TONIGHT: Louis Peterson's First Work, 'Take a Giant Step,' Deals With Challenge to Negro By LOUIS CALTA. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 24 Sep 1953: 38.</ref>
Dall did much work in television, appearing in guest roles on such shows as ''[[Lights Out (1946 TV series)|Lights Out]]'' ("Pit of the Dead"), ''[[The Clock (TV series)|The Clock]]'' ("A Right Smart Trick"), ''[[Studio One in Hollywood]]'' ("The Doctor's Wife"<ref>June Lockhart, John Dall Have Leads in TV Drama ''Chicago Daily Tribune'' (1923-1963); Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]05 Oct 1952: w_a8.</ref>), ''[[Broadway Television Theatre]]'' ("Outward Bound", "The Hasty Heart"), ''Suspense'' ("The Invisible Killer", "The Tenth Reunion"), ''[[General Electric Theatre]]'' ("The Coward of Fort Bennett") and ''[[Schlitz Playhouse]]'' ("And Practically Strangers"). Other theatre performances in stock included ''The Male Animal'' (1954).<ref>Tallulah, Maggie Vie as Attractions By Richard L. Coe. ''The Washington Post and Times Herald'' (1954-1959); Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C] 24 Aug 1954: 22.</ref>
Dall returned to Broadway for [[Leslie Stevens]]' ''Champagne Complex'', which had a short run in 1955.<ref>https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/champagne-complex-2511</ref><ref>'CHAMPAGNE' POPS IN COMEDY TONIGHT: Play by Stevens at the Cort Co-Stars Donald Cook, Polly Bergen and John Dall By LOUIS CALTA. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 12 Apr 1955: 26.</ref>
===Later career=== Dall's first film in eight years was ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' (1960), where he played a Roman soldier.<ref>FOX LISTS 34 FILMS IN RECORD BUDGET: Studio to Invest 66 Million in 1959 -- Musicians Unit Files Unfairness Charge By THOMAS M. PRYOR Special to The New York Times.. ''New York Times'' (1923–current file); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y] 22 Jan 1959: 27.</ref> He was the villain in MGM's ''[[Atlantis, the Lost Continent]]'' (1961), his final theatrical feature.<ref>FILM EVENTS: Two Stars Signed for Musical ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 11 June 1960: 10.</ref>
Dall guest starred in a number of episodes of TV's ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]'', playing different characters.
===Personal life=== Film historians [[William J. Mann]] and Karen Burroughs Hannsberry have remarked that Dall was gay but claimed in media interviews<ref name="cooke" /> to have had a brief marriage in the early 1940s.<ref name="kbh" /><ref>{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=William J.|authorlink1=William J. Mann|title=Behind the Screen: How Gays and Lesbians Shaped Hollywood|date=2001|publisher=Viking|isbn=0670030171|page=263}}</ref> No marriage certificate has come to light, and his death certificate records him as "never married". [[Hedda Hopper]] once linked his name with [[Jane Withers]] romantically.<ref>Hedda Hopper LOOKING AT HOLLYWOOD ''Los Angeles Times'' (1923–current File); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif] 22 Mar 1946: A7.</ref> Hollywood pimp [[Scotty Bowers]] has claimed that Dall was one of his most unusual clients, and liked to be tied upside down to trees in Laurel Canyon in the middle of the night. "He liked to hang upside down naked until morning. Once a week he wanted this."<ref>[https://twitter.com/ScottyBowers/status/1033814432143396864 Scotty Bowers: Twitter, 27 Aug 2018]</ref> According to music journalist Phil Milstein, at the time of his death Dall had lapsed into alcoholism and was living with his partner, actor Clement Brace (died 1996).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Milstein |first1=Phil |title=The Nightmare World of Dion McGregor |url=http://www.songpoemmusic.com/dion/chapters/9.htm |website=American Song-Poem Music Archives |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6W5ODg9sP?url=http://www.songpoemmusic.com/dion/chapters/9.htm |archivedate=February 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Israel|first1=Lee|authorlink1=Lee Israel|title=Can You Ever Forgive Me? Memoirs of a Literary Forger|date=2008|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=9781416553779|page=65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=colE1GDOS6oC&lpg=PA63&pg=PA65#v=onepage&q=Dall%20Brace%20lover|accessdate=February 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Death== [[File:John Dall - Death Certificate (1971).jpg|thumb|150px|Death certificate of John Dall.]] Dall sustained a serious fall while visiting London in October 1970, and died of cardiac arrest, a complication of [[myocarditis]], at his home in Beverly Hills, California on January 15, 1971, aged 50.<ref name=nyt /> His body was donated to medical science.<ref name="tdt">{{cite news|title=Actor, Brother of City Man, Is Dead|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/18458463/|work=The Daily Times|date=January 20, 1971|location=Salisbury, Maryland|page=7|quote=Worthington Thompson... is the only immediate survivor of John Dall... [who] died Friday in his Hollywood home of a heart attack. Mr. Thompson said today that his brother had never fully recovered from a fall last October in London. The 50-year-old actor was in Europe on business at the time... His grandfather was the late Dall Worthington of Baltimore County.|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref>{{refn|name=death|group=Note| Online sources attributing Dall's death to a "punctured lung" may be a garbled reference to his accident in London.}}
Dall's papers are held at the [[Margaret Herrick Library]] in Beverly Hills, California.<ref name=Herrick />

Notes |- | 1945 || ''[[The Corn Is Green (1945 film)|The Corn Is Green]]'' || Morgan Evans || |- | 1947 || ''[[Something in the Wind]]'' || Donald Read || |- | 1948 || ''[[Another Part of the Forest (film)|Another Part of the Forest]]'' || John Bagtry || |- | 1948 || ''[[Rope (film)|Rope]]'' || Brandon Shaw || |- | 1950 || ''[[Gun Crazy]]'' || Bart Tare || |- | 1950 || ''[[The Man Who Cheated Himself]]'' || Andy Cullen || |- | 1960 || ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' || Marcus Glabrus || |- | 1961 || ''[[Atlantis, the Lost Continent]]'' || Zaren || |}

Reese || "The Coward of Fort Bennett" |- | 1959 || ''[[Schlitz Playhouse of Stars|Schlitz Playhouse]]'' || Hugh Mitchell || "And Practically Strangers" |- | 1962 || ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]''|| Julian Kirk || "The Case of the Lonely Eloper" |- | 1962 || ''Perry Mason''|| Edward Franklin || "The Case of the Weary Watchdog" |- | 1963 || ''Perry Mason''|| Colin Durant || "The Case of the Reluctant Model" |- | 1965 || ''Perry Mason''|| Roan Daniel || Episode - "The Case of the Laughing Lady", (final appearance) |}
==Radio credits== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Program !! Episode/source |- | 1953 || ''[[The United States Steel Hour#Theatre Guild on the Air|Theatre Guild on the Air]]'' || ''[[Quiet Wedding (play)|Quiet Wedding]]''<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirby|first1=Walter|title=Better Radio Programs for the Week|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2676130/the_decatur_daily_review/|agency=The Decatur Daily Review|date=March 15, 1953|page=46|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = June 25, 2015}} {{Open access}}</ref> |}
==Discography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Album !! Credits !! Label !! {{Infobox ethnic group |group=Koreans in Mongolia |population=2,284 South Koreans (2013){{citation|chapterurl=http://www.mofa.go.kr/webmodule/common/download.jsp?boardid=232&tablename=TYPE_DATABOARD&seqno=fcefeefd6f8e05d012031027&fileseq=00b03707a059027fc7069fbf|chapter=남아시아태평양|title={{asiantitle|재외동포현황|||a}}|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade|date=2013-09-30|accessdate=2015-04-30|page=103}}
200 North Koreans (2008)
Plus an unknown number of [[North Korean defectors]] |popplace=[[Ulaanbaatar]] |languages=[[Korean language|Korean]], [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]] |related=[[Korean diaspora]] }} '''Koreans in Mongolia''' form one of the [[Korean diaspora]] communities in Asia. They consist of both [[North Korea|North]] and [[South Korea]]n expatriates. ==South Koreans== ===Population and business activities=== In 1994, there were estimated to be around 100 South Korean expatriates in Mongolia.{{citation|date=2003-08-28|accessdate=2009-01-27|periodical=Dongpo News|title='몽골에서 안경점 하는 한인도 있습니다' ('In Mongolia, there are even Koreans running eyeglasses shops')|last=Gang|first=Guk-jin|url=http://www.dongponews.net/news/articleView.html?idxno=1025}} Official statistics from South Korea's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (South Korea)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade]] showed 270 of their nationals in Mongolia in 1997, and about eight times as many by 2013.{{citation|url=http://www.okf.or.kr/data/status_AS.jsp|title=재외동포현황 - 아시아 (Status of overseas compatriots - Asia)|publisher=Overseas Korean Foundation|year=2005|accessdate=2009-01-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212042424/http://www.okf.or.kr/data/status_AS.jsp|archivedate=2006-02-12|df=}} Some unofficial estimates suggest that their population might be as large as 3,500 individuals.{{citation|periodical=YTN News|url=http://www.ytn.co.kr/global_korean/global_view.php?key=200807050858441453&s_mcd=0930&s_hcd=19|date=2008-07-05|accessdate=2009-01-27|title=유혈 사태, 평온 회복 중}} Aside from residents, the number of South Korean tourists has also shown an upward trend, reaching 40,000 individuals in 2007.{{citation|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_international/298846.html |periodical=The Hankyoreh |title=In Mongolia, sex tourism by S. Korean males leads to anti-Korean sentiment: With Korean men contributing to growth of industry, the damage to Korea’s image has increased |date=2008-07-15 |accessdate=2009-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801003014/http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_international/298846.html |archivedate=2008-08-01 |df= }} Many South Korean expatriates operate small businesses; the number of businesses in Mongolia funded by South Korean capital was estimated at 1,500 {{asof|2008|lc=on}}. The various types of businesses include restaurants serving [[Korean cuisine]], [[Karaoke Box|karaoke bars]], and even eyeglass shops.{{citation|url=http://www.donga.com/docs/magazine/viewer.php?mgz_part=weekly&n=200301090500054|title=몽골 상류층 사로잡은 ‘한국의 맛’ (The 'Korean flavour' captivating Mongolian high society)|periodical=Weekly Dong-A|date=2003-01-09|accessdate=2009-01-28|issue=368|pages=57–58|last=U|first=Gil}} A weekend language and culture school for Korean children was set up in 1998 by a local Korean church.{{citation|title=Ulaanbaatar MK School/몽골선교사자녀학교|accessdate=2009-05-15|url=http://www.mkschool.org/index.php}} Under a bilateral agreement, both South Koreans working in Mongolia as well as [[Mongolians in South Korea|Mongolians working in South Korea]] are exempted from otherwise-mandatory contributions to the national pension plans of the country they reside in.{{citation|title=South Korean president in Mongolia|date=2006-05-18|accessdate=2009-01-27|periodical=The Mongol Messenger|url=http://www.mongolmessenger.mn/issue/060518.php}} ===Ethnic tensions === The growth of the South Korean presence has caused some tensions with their Mongolian hosts. In 2005, Korean-owned businesses in Ulan Bator which displayed ''[[hangul]]'' signs were ordered to switch them to English or Mongolian only, a situation which South Korean news agency [[YTN]] attributed to growing Mongolian nationalism.{{citation|url=http://www.ytn.co.kr/global_korean/global_view.php?key=200512292116485263&s_mcd=0930&s_hcd=19|date=2005-12-29|accessdate=2009-01-27|periodical=YTN News|title=몽골에 부는 민족주의 바람 (The wind of ethnonationalism blowing in Mongolia)}} Among the numerous South Korean owned businesses are a number of [[karaoke]] bars operating as fronts for prostitution, which are frequented by clients of South Korean-run businesses in Mongolia (growing from just one in 2002 to an estimated fifty as of 2005). ==North Koreans== ===Migrant workers=== [[File:North Korean migrant worker numbers in Asia map.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Number of North Korean migrant workers in Asia]] As of May 2008, roughly 200 North Korean citizens worked in Mongolia.{{citation|title=Parliament considers law to expand North Korean employment in Mongolia|periodical=Mongolia Web|date=2008-05-12|accessdate=2009-01-27|url=http://www.mongolia-web.com/1751-parliament-considers-law-expand-north-korean-employment-mongolia}} In February 2008, Ulan Bator and Pyongyang reached an agreement which would allow as many as 5,300 North Korean workers to come to Mongolia over the following five years.{{citation|periodical=Human Rights Watch|title=Mongolia: Protect Rights of North Korean Migrant Workers|date=2008-08-19|accessdate=2009-01-27|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2008/08/19/mongolia-protect-rights-north-korean-migrant-workers}} The relevant agreement came before the [[State Great Hural]] for approval in May that year. An open letter from American NGO [[Human Rights Watch]] in August called on Mongolian Minister of Social Welfare and Labor [[Damdiny Demberel]] to ensure that the workers' freedom of expression, movement, and association would be respected; North Korean workers in similar positions in Europe were often denied such rights by their North Korean government minders. The South Korean ambassador described Mongolia's decision to import North Korean workers as "problematic".{{citation|title=BCM Mongolia Meeting: Peter Morrow Hands Over Chair|date=2008-07-04|accessdate=2009-01-27|periodical=Mongolia Web|url=http://www.mongolia-web.com/1866-bcm-mongolia-meeting-peter-morrow-hands-over-chair}} ===Defectors=== [[File:North Korean defector routes map.png|thumb|upright=1.5|North Korean defectors often pass through Mongolia on their way to South Korea.]] {{asof|2006}}, it was estimated that 500 [[North Korean defectors]] entered Mongolia each month, largely by way of neighbouring [[China]].{{citation|periodical=Gulf Times |publication-place=Qatar |url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=119099&version=1&template_id=45&parent_id=25 |date=2006-11-24 |accessdate=2009-01-27 |title=Mongolia not planning camps for N. Koreans |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930201341/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=119099&version=1&template_id=45&parent_id=25 |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }} As early as 2004, some South Korean citizens' groups had begun laying plans to construct camps in Mongolia to house North Korean refugees; however, they were denied permission by the Mongolian government.{{citation|periodical=Radio Free Asia|url=http://www.rfa.org/korean/news/2004/11/09/mongol/|archiveurl=http://www.rfa.org/korean/news/2004/11/09/mongol/|archivedate=2005-11-14|date=2004-11-09|accessdate=2009-01-27|title=몽골, 탈북자 정착촌건립 허용 못한다고 (Mongolia cannot give permission to set up camps for North Korean defectors)}} In September 2005, South Korean NGO Rainbow Foundation stated that they had been granted 1.3 square kilometres of land near Ulan Bator, and would soon begin construction on a centre which could house as many as 200 North Korean refugees {{citation|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003013139/http://www.rfa.org/english/news/politics/2005/09/06/nkorea_mongolia/|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/politics/2005/09/06/nkorea_mongolia/|date=2005-09-06|accessdate=2009-01-27|archivedate=2006-10-03|title=Center Offers Haven For North Korean Defectors in Mongolia|periodical=Radio Free Asia}} However, during his November 2006 trip to Beijing, [[Prime Minister of Mongolia|Mongolian prime minister]] [[Miyeegombyn Enkhbold]] denied reports that his country was planning to set up any refugee camps for North Koreans, though he reaffirmed that they would be treated in a humanitarian manner. In October 2008, [[President of South Korea|South Korean president]] [[Lee Myung-bak]] was reported to have ordered his officials to look further into the possibility of setting up a camp for them in Mongolia.{{citation|url=http://mongolia-web.com/2019-report-mongolia-could-host-north-korean-refugee-camp|periodical=Mongolia Web|title=Report: Mongolia could host North Korean refugee camp|date=2008-10-02|accessdate=2009-01-27}} The Mongolian government does have facilities to provide shelter for North Korean refugees on their territory; in December 2007, [[Vitit Muntarbhorn]], the [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Special Rapporteur|Special Rapporteur]] on Human Rights in North Korea, praised Mongolia's treatment of North Korean refugees in an official report, noting that they had made commendable progress in improving such facilities since his previous visit.{{citation|title=Mongolia praised for improved treatment of North Korean refugees|periodical=Mongolia Web|date=2007-12-25|accessdate=2009-01-27|url=http://www.mongolia-web.com/1558-mongolia-praised-improved-treatment-north-korean-refugees}} Both the Mongolian and South Korean governments' policies towards refugees have shifted several times. In June 2007, Mongolia began to turn North Korean refugees away from their borders, reportedly with the aim of improving [[Mongolia–North Korea relations|their diplomatic relations with North Korea]].{{citation|title=Mongolia closes border to fleeing North Koreans|periodical=Mongolia Web|url=http://www.mongolia-web.com/1072-mongolia-closes-borders-fleeing-north-koreans|date=2007-06-06|accessdate=2009-01-27}} Similarly, in October 2007, the South Korean side was reported to be "closing the door" to North Korean refugees in Mongolia and Southeast Asia; North Korea watcher [[Andrei Lankov]], a professor at Seoul's [[Kookmin University]], attributed this to a deliberate policy by the South Korean government to minimise the number of new refugees.{{citation|periodical=Mongolia Web|title=North Koreans may find door shut to South Korea|url=http://www.mongolia-web.com/1392-north-koreans-mongolia-may-find-door-shut-south-korea|accessdate=2009-01-27|date=2007-10-02}} ==See also== *[[Ethnic Chinese in Mongolia]] ==References== {{reflist|2|refs= {{citation|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9801E7DE133FF931A25753C1A9659C8B63|periodical=The New York Times|last=Brooke|first=James|authorlink=James Brooke|title=Mongolians and Koreans: Twins With Minimal Sibling Rivalry|date=2003-10-12|accessdate=2009-01-27}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.kmnews.co.kr/ ''Monggol Gyomin Sinmun''], a Korean-language news site aimed at South Korean expatriates in Mongolia {{Korean diaspora}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mongolia]] [[Category:Korean diaspora in Asia|Mongolia]] [[Category:Overseas Korean groups|Mongolia]] [[Category:Mongolian people of Korean descent| ]]
