Conviction [nJ]. ====2006–2008==== '''2006'''{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/page:2/date:2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009104746/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/page%3A2/date%3A2006 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=9 October 2011 |title=Journalists |publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org |accessdate=18 October 2014 |df= }} * 8 January – Vagif Kochetkov, newly appointed ''[[Trud (newspaper)|Trud]]'' correspondent in the region, killed and robbed in [[Tula, Russia|Tula]]. Acquittal [nJ]. * 26 February – Ilya Zimin, worked for [[NTV Russia]] television channel, killed in [[Moscow]] flat. Suspect in Moldova trial. Acquittal [nJ]. * 4 May – Oksana Teslo, media worker, Moscow Region. Arson attack on dacha. Homicide [nJ]. * 14 May – Oleg Barabyshkin, director of radio station, Chelyabinsk. Homicide. Conviction [nJ]. * 25 June – Anton Kretenchuk, cameraman, local Channel 38 TV, killed in [[Rostov-on-Don]]. Homicide. Conviction [nJ]. * 25 July – Yevgeny Gerasimenko, journalist with ''Saratovsky Rasklad'' newspaper. Murdered in [[Saratov]]. Conviction [nJ]. * 31 July – Anatoly Kozulin, retired freelance journalist. Ukhta, Komi. Incident not Confirmed [nJ]. * 7 October – [[Anna Politkovskaya]], commentator with ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', [[Moscow]], shot in her apartment building's elevator;.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5416218.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - Chechen war reporter found dead|author=|date=|website=news.BBC.co.uk|access-date=15 June 2017}}[http://2006.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2006/82n/n82n-s05.shtml Agent unknown (Russian)] ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]''[https://www.theguardian.com/russia/article/0,,1890838,00.html Anna Politkovskaya] ''[[The Guardian]]''{{lang-ru|[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927212328/http://www.gdf.ru/arh/mort/2006.shtml Погибшие журналисты - 2006]}} Glasnost Defence Foundation Four accused in contract killing, acquitted in February 2009 [J]. * 16 October – Anatoly Voronin, Itar-TASS news agency, Moscow. Homicide [nJ]. * 28 December – Vadim Kuznetsov, editor-in-chief of ''World & Home. Saint Petersburg'' magazine, killed in [[Saint Petersburg]]. Homicide [nJ]. Investigation under Incitement to Suicide (Article 110) [?J]. * 15 March – Leonid Etkind, director at ''Karyera'' newspaper. Abduction and homicide in Vodnik, Saratov Region. Conviction [nJ]. * 5 April – Vyacheslav Ifanov, Novoye televidenie Aleiska, cameraman. Previously attacked by local military. Aleisk, Altai. Incident not Confirmed [?J]. * April – Marina Pisareva, deputy head of Russian office of German media group [[Bertelsmann]] was found dead at her country cottage outside [[Moscow]] in April{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/World/Bertelsmann-manager-murdered-in-Russia/2007/07/16/1184559707604.html |location=Melbourne |work=The Age |title=Bertelsmann manager 'murdered in Russia' |date=16 July 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lenizdat.ru/cgi-bin/redir?l=ru&b=1&i=1052012 |title=Bertelsmann: Марина Писарева убита не из-за работы |date=2007-07-16 |accessdate=4 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120803212315/http://www.lenizdat.ru/cgi-bin/redir?l=ru&b=1&i=1052012 |archivedate=3 August 2012 }} '''2008''' (Putin's final months as president) * 8 February – Yelena Shestakova, former journalist, St Petersburg. Killer sent to psychiatric prison. Homicide [nJ]. * 21 March – Gadji Abashilov, chief of Dagestan State TV & Radio Company [[VGTRK]], shot in his car in Makhachkala. Homicide [?J]. * 21 March – Ilyas Shurpayev, [[Republic of Dagestan|Dagestani]] journalist covering Caucasus on [[Channel One (Russia)|Channel One]], was strangled with a belt by robbers in Moscow.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/21mar2008/shurpaev.html|title=Новости NEWSru.com :: Убит журналист Первого канала Ильяс Шурпаев, его задушили ремнем|publisher=Newsru.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/lib/14188063/|title=Lenta.ru: Шурпаев, Ильяс|publisher=Lenta.ru|accessdate=18 October 2014}} Alleged killers tracked to Tajikistan and convicted there of his murder. Homicide [?J]. ===The Medvedev presidency=== [[File:Евлоев, Магомед Яхьяевич (8 сентября 2007).JPG|right|thumb|[[Magomed Yevloyev]] was shot and killed while in police custody in Ingushetia on 31 August 2008.]] ====2008==== * 31 August – [[Magomed Yevloyev]] was shot dead while in police custody in [[Ingushetia]]. Yevloyev was the founder of the opposition website [[Ingushetia.org]] and was known for his regular criticism of Ingush President [[Murat Zyazikov]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7590719.stm Ingushetia website owner killed], [[BBC News]], 31 August 2008[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24272873-12377,00.html Kremlin critic found dead], ''[[The Australian]]'', 31 August 2008[https://web.archive.org/web/20080902235548/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2008%2F08%2F31%2Finternational%2Fi072332D67.DTL&tsp=1 Deputy says Russian police kill Web site owner], [[Associated Press]], 31 August 2008 The police officer involved in the killing, Ibragim Yevloyev, was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter and sentenced to two years in prison.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8407819.stm|title=Russia policeman jailed for death of Kremlin critic|date=2009-12-11|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-GB}} * 2 September – [[Abdulla Alishayev]] was shot several times by unknown assailants in Makhachkala, Dagestan, and died in hospital.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-dagestan-journalist/journalist-in-russias-dagestan-killed-idUSL329370720080903|title=Journalist in Russia's Dagestan killed|last=Baldwin|first=Chris|date=2008-09-03|work=Reuters|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US}} Alishayev was the television host of TV-Chirkei and was known for his opposition to Islamic fundamentalism within the republic and Russia as a whole.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/anti-radical-islam-reporter-killed-in-south-russia-917692.html|title=Anti-radical Islam reporter killed in south Russia|last=|first=|date=2008-09-03|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-GB}} * 30 December – Shafig Amrakhov was shot and wounded by an unknown assailant at his apartment in [[Murmansk]] and later died in hospital. Amrakhov was the editor of the RIA 51 news agency and criticized the economic policies of Yuri Yevdokimov, the governor of [[Murmansk Oblast]].{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/2009/shafig-amrakhov.php|title=Shafig Amrakhov|publisher=Cpj.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}} ====2009==== * 4 January – Vladislav Zakharchuk died in a fire that engulfed a newspaper office in [[Vladivostok]], [[Primorsky Krai]]. Zakharchuk was the advertisement manager for the newspaper ''Arsenyevskie Vesti''. The newspaper was known for its criticism of the authorities in the krai and its chief editor and journalists have faced fines and imprisonment in the past.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/279 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416231039/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/279|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-04-16|title=Vladislav Zakharchuk|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}} * 19 January – [[Stanislav Markelov]] was shot and killed by a masked gunman in Moscow alongside Anastasia Baburova. Markelov was a lawyer who worked with ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'' and brought many cases against the Russian military, Chechen warlords, and neo-Nazi groups.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/20/world/europe/20chechnya.html|title=Leading Russian Rights Lawyer Killed|last=Schwirtz|first=Michael|date=2009-01-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} * 19 January – [[Anastasia Baburova]] died alongside Stanislav Marekelov after being shot at in Moscow. Baburova was a journalist-in-training for ''Novaya Gazeta'' and was known for investigating neo-Nazi activity in Russia.{{Cite news|url=https://jamestown.org/program/the-russian-security-services-the-prime-murder-suspect/|title=The Russian Security Services—The Prime Murder Suspect - Jamestown|last=Felgenhauer|first=Pavel|date=2009-01-22|work=Jamestown|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US}} * 30 March – Sergei Protazanov was found unconscious at his home in [[Khimki]], [[Moscow Oblast]], and later died in hospital. Authorities and relatives believed he was poisoned. Protazanov was the page designer for ''Grazhdanskoye Soglasiye'', the only opposition newspaper in the city, and was seriously beaten by assailants a few days prior to his death.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/Moscow_Regional_Journalist_Dies_Mysteriously/1565896.html|title=Moscow Regional Journalist Dies Mysteriously|last=Coalson|first=Robert|date=2009-04-01|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}} * 29 June – Vyacheslav Yaroshenko died of wounds he received from a severe beating by an unknown assailant in April in [[Rostov-on-Don]], [[Rostov Oblast]]. Yaroshenko was the chief editor of the ''Korruptsiya i Prestupnost'' newspaper and prior to his beating, the newspaper published multiple articles alleging corruption in the Oblast's government, police, and prosecutor's office.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2009/jun/30/russia-press-freedom|title=Another Russian journalist dies mysteriously|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|date=2009-06-30|website=The Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-03}} * 15 July – [[Natalia Estemirova]] was abducted and then killed in Grozny, Chechnya. Her body was later found near [[Nazran]], Ingushetia. Estemirova was a human rights activist for [[Memorial (society)|Memorial]] who worked with journalists of ''Novaya Gazeta'' and occasionally published in the newspaper herself. She was known for investigating murders and kidnappings in Chechnya and was a colleague of Anna Politkovskaya.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8152351.stm|title=Russian activist found murdered|date=2009-07-15|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-GB}} * 11 August – [[Malik Akhmedilov]] was found shot dead near Makhachkala, Dagestan. Akhemdilov was the deputy chief editor of ''Khakikat'' and the chief editor of the ''Sogratl'' newspapers, which focused on civic and political issues in the republic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/Investigative_Journalist_Killed_in_Russias_Daghestan/1797391.html|title=Investigative Journalist Killed in Russia's Daghestan|date=2009-08-11|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}} * 25 October – Maksharip Aushev was shot dead in Nalchik, Kabardino-Balkaria. Aushev worked on multiple human rights cases in neighboring Ingushetia and was the operator of Ingushetia.org following the death of Magomed Yevloyev in 2008.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/oct/25/opposition-activist-shot-dead-ingushetia|title=Opposition activist shot dead in Ingushetia|date=2009-10-25|website=The Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-03}} * 16 November – Olga Kotovskaya died after falling out of a window on the 14th-floor of a building in [[Kaliningrad]]. Authorities classified the death as suicide while colleagues believe she was murdered for her work. Kotovskaya was the co-founder of the Kaskad radio and television station, which was embroiled in an ownership lawsuit brought by Vladimir Pirogov, the former vice governor of [[Kaliningrad Oblast]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/The_Suspicious_Death_Of_Russian_Journalist_Olga_Kotovskaya/1893177.html|title=The Suspicious Death Of Russian Journalist Olga Kotovskaya|date=2009-12-02|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}} ====2010==== * 20 January – Konstantin Popov died from a beating received by Russian police while in custody in [[Tomsk]]. Popov was the co-founder and director of the ''Tema'' newspaper and was allegedly tortured prior to his death.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/russian-journalist-dies-after-police-beating/article1437815/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125170955/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/russian-journalist-dies-after-police-beating/article1437815/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-01-25|title=Russian journalist dies after police beating|first=Steve|last=Gutterman|agency=AP|work=Globe and Mail|date=2010-01-20}} * 23 February – Ivan Stepanov was stabbed to death at his dacha in [[Khilok, Zabaykalsky Krai|Khilok]], [[Zabaykalsky Krai]]. Stepanov was a local correspondent for the ''Zabaikalsky rabochy'' newspaper and the author of three books that were popular in his district.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/326 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416231122/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/326|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-04-16|title=Journalists in Russia database, Stepanov|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2014-10-18}} * 20 March – Maxim Zuyev went missing and was later found murdered in a flat he was renting in Kaliningrad. Zuyev was a reporter for multiple newspapers in Kaliningrad Oblast and was a moderator for the Koenigsberg journalist society.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/327 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416231127/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/327 |dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-04-16|title=Maxim Zuyev|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2014-10-18}} * 5 May – Shamil Aliyev was shot and killed by unknown gunmen in Makhachkala, Dagestan. Aliyev was the founder of the Priboi and Vatan radio stations and director of the TNT-Makhachkala television network and was known for his anti-[[Wahhabism|Wahhabist]] views, which were reflected in his radio and TV stations.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/328|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208090353/http://www.journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/328|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-02-08|title=Shamil Aliyev|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2014-10-18}} * 13 May – Said Ibragimov was shot dead while travelling with a team of repairmen to restore a television transmitter that was damaged by militants the previous day in Ayazi his Niva, Dagestan. Ibragimov was the director of TBS, a local television channel.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/329|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112080630/http://journalists-in-russia.org:80/journalists/view/329|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-05-13|title=Said Ibragimov|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2018-06-03}} * 25 June – Dmitry Okkert, Moscow. A presenter with the Expert TV channel, Okkert was found stabbed to death in his own apartment. The director of the Expert media holding, Valery Fadeyev, does not believe that the brutal killing of his colleague was linked to his journalistic activities. * 25 July – Bella Ksalova was fatally injured and later died in hospital after being hit by a vehicle near her home in [[Cherkessk]], [[Karachay-Cherkessia]]. Ksalova was a correspondent for the Caucasian Knot website and news agency and wrote highly critical articles of local authorities. The driver, Arsen Abaikhanov, plead guilty and was sentenced three years in a penal colony.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208073704/http://www.journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/331|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-02-08|title=Bella Ksalova|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2014-10-18}} * 1 August – Malika Betiyeva was killed along with four members of her family when a speeding vehicle hit hers on a highway in Chechnya. Betiyeva was the deputy chief editor of the ''Molodyozhnaya smena'' newspaper and a correspondent for ''Dosh'' magazine. She was known for writing about lawless behavior of government agencies in Chechnya and her worked had to be published under an assumed name for her own safety.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/330|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112080635/http://journalists-in-russia.org:80/journalists/view/330|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-05-13|title=Malika Betiyeva|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=2018-06-03}} * 11 August – Magomed Sultanmagomedov was killed in a drive-by-shooting in Makhachkala, Dagestan. Sultanmagomedov was the director of the Makhachkala TV station and was previously a target of an attempted bombing in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifex.org/russia/2010/08/20/sultanmagomedov_killed/|title=Journalist killed in Makhachkala |publisher=IFEX|accessdate=18 October 2014}} * 23 October – Yevgeny Fedotov died in hospital due to head injuries he received in a violent quarrel with his neighbour in [[Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai|Chita]], Zabaykalsky Krai. The latter has been charged with manslaughter.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/334|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018161554/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/334|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 October 2014|title=Journalists|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}} ====2011==== * 15 December – [[Gadzhimurat Kamalov]] was shot six times in a drive-by shooting outside his newspaper's office in Makhachkala, Dagestan. Kamalov owned the media company Svoboda Slova and was known for investigating corruption and rebel activity in the republic.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/339|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019205748/http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/339|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 October 2012|title=Journalists|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}} ===Under Putin=== ====2012==== * 7 July – Alexander Khodzinsky was stabbed to death by local businessman and former deputy mayor Gennady Zhigarev in [[Tulun]], [[Irkutsk Oblast]]. Khodzinsky campaigned against abusive and illegal practices in the construction of a shopping mall in the town center since 2007 and would regular complain to president Dmitry Medvedev and governor [[Dmitry Mezentsev]] about the issue.{{cite web | url=http://www.journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/343 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019205803/http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/343 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2012-10-19 | title=Alexandr Khodzinsky | publisher=Journalists in Russia | accessdate=2014-08-13}} * 5 December – Kazbek Gekkiev was shot dead at a street in [[Nalchik]], [[Kabardino-Balkaria]], after receiving death threats from local extremists. Gekkiev worked for various local TV programs in the republic.{{cite web | url=http://www.journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/344 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925100307/http://journalists-in-russia.org/jir/journalists/view/344 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2013-09-25 | title=Kazbek Gekkiev | publisher=Journalists in Russia | accessdate=2014-08-13}} ====2013==== * 9 July – [[Akhmednabi Akhmednabiyev]] was killed while driving just 50 metres from his house on the outskirts of Makhachkala, Dagestan, after receiving numerous death threats. Akhmednabiyev was the deputy editor of the newspaper ''Novoe Delo'' and regularly wrote about the politics of the republic and human rights issues in the North Caucasus. He was previously the victim of an assassination attempt back in January 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/226823/|title= Journalist assassinated outside home in Dagestan|work=Кавказский Узел|accessdate=18 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2013/07/09/Journalist-assassinated-outside-home-in-Dagestan/UPI-29191373380402/|title=Journalist assassinated outside home in Dagestan|work=UPI|accessdate=18 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/07/09/russia-journalist-killed|title=Russia: Journalist Killed - Authorities Ignored Threats, Attacks Against Him|publisher=Hrw.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/488131/20130709/dagestan-russian-journalist-akhmednabi-akhmednabiev-gunned-down.htm|title=Dagestan: Russian Journalist Akhmednabi Akhmednabiev Gunned Down|work=International Business Times UK|accessdate=18 October 2014}} ====2014==== * 1 August – [[Timur Kuashev]] was abducted from his home and later found dead in Nalchik, Kabardino-Balkaria.{{cite web | url=http://en.rsf.org/russia-independent-journalist-murdered-in-01-08-2014,46745.html | title=INDEPENDENT JOURNALIST MURDERED IN KABARDINO-BALKARIA | publisher=Reporterts without Borders | date=2014-08-01 | accessdate=2014-08-02}} Kuashev worked for the magazine ''Dosh'' and received death threats and was previously stopped by local police a number of times.{{cite web | url=http://eng.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/28190/ | title=In KBR, Circassian activist and journalist Timur Kuashev released from police | publisher=Caucasian Knot | date=2014-05-21 | accessdate=2014-08-02}} ====2016==== * March 31 – Dmitry Tsilikin was stabbed to death in his flat in [[Saint Petersburg]]. Tsilikin wrote for many independent media outlets and mainly focused on social issues and human rights.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/russia-journalist-found-stabbed-st-petersburg/27648112.html|title=Independent Russian Journalist Found Dead Of Stab Wounds|last=Service|first=RFE/RL's Russian|date=2016-04-01|newspaper=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=English|access-date=2016-04-01}} The suspected killer is neo-nazi Sergey Kosyrev. The murder is attributed to Tsilikin's homosexual orientation.{{cite web|url=http://www.interpretermag.com/russia-update-april-15-2016/#13348|title=Kremlin Propagandists Claim Browder Complicit in Magnitsky Death; He Sets Record Straight|website=www.interpretermag.com|access-date=2016-04-18}} ====2017==== * March 17 – Yevgeny Khamaganov died of unexplained causes in [[Ulan-Ude]], [[Buryatia]]. Khamaganov was known for writing articles that criticized the federal government and was allegedly beaten by unknown assailants on March 10.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-journalist-dies-unexplained-circumstances/28375653.html|title=Russian Journalist Dies In Unexplained Circumstances|last=|first=|date=2017-03-17|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|access-date=2017-03-17}} * April 19 – Journalist and former prisoner of conscience [[Nikolay Andrushchenko]] died in Saint Petersburg from wounds that he received from a severe beating by unknown assailants on March 9. Andrushchenko was the co-founder of the newspaper ''Novy Petersburg'' and was previously jailed in 2009 by a city court for "libel and extremism".{{Cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-journalist-andrushchenko-dies-sever-beating/28439320.html|title=Russian Journalist, Putin Critic Dies After Severe Beating|last=|first=|date=2017-04-19|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|access-date=2017-04-19}} * May 24 – Dmitry Popkov was found dead from gunshot wounds at a bathhouse close to his home in [[Minusinsk]], [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]]. Popkov was the chief editor of the newspaper ''Ton-M'' and was known for investigating police corruption.{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/news/anti-corruption-journalist-murdered-in-russia-58082|title=Anti-Corruption Journalist Murdered in Russia|last=|first=|date=2017-05-25|work=The Moscow Times|access-date=2017-05-25|language=en}} * September 8 - The body of Andrey Ruskov was found in the [[Bira River]] in [[Birobidzhan]], [[Jewish Autonomous Oblast]]. Ruskov worked for the Bestvideo Broadcasting Studio.{{Cite web|url=http://nabat.news/2017/09/08/po-faktu-tainstvennoj-gibeli-30-letnego-zhurnalista-andreya-ruskova-vozbuzhdeno-ugolovnoe-delo/|title=On the fact of the mysterious death of a 30-year-old journalist Andrei Ruskova criminal case|last=|first=|date=2017-09-08|website=Habat|language=Russian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-08}} ====2018==== * April 15 – Maksim Borodin died of injuries from falling out of a window at his apartment in [[Yekaterinburg]], [[Sverdlovsk Oblast]], on April 12. Authorities classified the death as suicide while colleagues reject the notion. Borodin regularly wrote on crime, corruption, and [[Wagner Group|the recent involvement of Russian mercenaries in Syria]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/yekaterinburg-journalist-dies-after-falling-from-apartment-window/29168826.html|title=Russian Investigative Reporter Dies After Fall From Window; Editor Rejects Suicide|date=2018-04-15|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|access-date=2018-04-15}} *July 23 – Denis Suvorov was found dead after being stabbed by an unknown assailant in [[Nizhny Novgorod]]. Suvorov worked for the Vesti-Privolzhye television station and was an editor for the Vesti.Nizhny Novgorod internet portal.{{Cite news|url=https://newsnn.ru/news/society/24-07-2018/zhurnalist-gtrk-nizhniy-novgorod-denis-suvorov-tragicheski-pogib-23-iyulya|title=Denis Suvorov, journalist of State TV and Radio Company Nizhny Novgorod, was found dead on July 23|last=|first=|date=2018-07-24|work=NewsNN|access-date=2018-09-11|language=ru-RU}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.idelreal.org/a/29387942.html|title=Denis Suvorov, journalist of VGTRK, was killed in Nizhny Novgorod|last=|first=|date=2018-07-24|work=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|access-date=2018-09-11|language=ru}} * July 31 – Sergei Grachyov went missing in Nizhny Novgorod on July 21 after taking a reporting trip there from Moscow. His body was found 11 days later. Grachuov worked for the ''Argumenty i Fakty'' newspaper.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/missing-russian-journalist-found-dead-in-nizhny-novgorod/29404682.html|title=Missing Russian Journalist Found Dead In Nizhny Novgorod|last=|first=|date=2018-08-01|website=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-01}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aif.ru/society/media/pogib_zhurnalist_aif_sergey_grachev|title=The journalist of "AiF" Sergei Grachev|last=|first=|date=2018-08-01|website=Argumenty i Fakty|language=Russian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-01}} *September 10 – Yegor Orlov disappeared on September 7 after leaving for work in [[Naberezhnye Chelny]], [[Tatarstan]]. His body was later found in a river in the [[Yelabuzhsky District]]. Orlov was a correspondent and presenter at Chelny REN-TV.{{Cite web|url=http://prokazan.ru/news/view/128169|title=In Tatarstan, a journalist was found dead in the river|last=|first=|date=2018-09-10|website=Pro Kazan|language=ru|access-date=2018-09-11}} ==Journalists killed reporting on Chechnya== This category overlaps with that for Russia as a whole. It highlights the link between journalism, public activism, and human rights activists. In their different ways, the deaths of Dmitry Krikoryants, Dmitry Kholodov, Nadezhda Chaikova, [[Viktor Popkov]],{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/72|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726211853/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/view/72|dead-url=yes|archive-date=26 July 2011|title=Journalists in Russia, Popkov|publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}} Anna Politkovskaya, Anastasia Baburova, Stanislav Markelov, and Natalia Estemirova all show that the troubled situation in the small North Caucasian republic reaches well beyond its formal borders. For all who died, or were fatally wounded in Chechnya, see records in the IFJ database.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/federaldistrictplus:Chechnya |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819032825/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/federaldistrictplus%3AChechnya |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 August 2011 |title=Journalists |publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org |accessdate=18 October 2014 |df= }} Those killed in locations near or far from the North Caucasian republic (e.g. Natalya Alyakina, Anna Politkovskaya) whose deaths were also a consequence of the armed conflict in Chechnya. ===1993=== * 14–15 April – Dmitry Krikoryants, Grozny.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/surname:krikoryants |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726211836/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/surname%3Akrikoryants |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 July 2011 |title=Journalists in Russia, An online database, Krikoryants |publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org |accessdate=18 October 2014 |df= }} Murdered over a year before open conflict broke out in Chechnya (first between pro-Dudayev and pro-Moscow factions, then with the intervention of federal forces). The killing of Krikoryants was linked to his investigation of the corrupt activities of the local regime, at home and abroad. ===1st Chechen war, 1994–1996=== *1994 – [[Cynthia Elbaum]]. On assignment for ''Time'' magazine (USA), Elbaum was photographing the streets of [[Grozny]] when she was killed in a Russian bombing raid.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E6DB1E38F930A15751C1A962958260 As Russian Pilots Close In: 'It Was Terrifying'] ([[The New York Times]], 24 December 1994) *31 December 1994 – [[Vladimir Zhitarenko]], a veteran [[military]] [[correspondent]] for the [[Russian armed forces]] [[Daily newspaper|daily]] ''[[Krasnaya Zvezda]]'' (Red Star), was hit by two sniper bullets outside the town of Tolstoy-Yurt, near the Chechen capital of Grozny. *[[Nina Yefimova]], a reporter for the new ''Vozrozhdenie'' (Revival) newspaper was abducted from her apartment and killed together with her mother. Journalists in Grozny and Moscow believe that her murder was related to stories she had published on crime in Chechnya. *10 January 1995 – [[Jochen Piest]], a correspondent with ''Stern'' magazine (Germany), was killed in an attack by a Chechen rebel against a Russian mine-clearing unit in Chervlyonna, a village 24 kilometers northeast of Grozny. ''Rossiskaya Gazeta'' correspondent Vladimir Sorokin was wounded in the attack; Piest was fatally hit by three bullets. *22 May 1995 – [https://web.archive.org/web/20040908204653/http://www.rorypecktrust.org/benefic/kerimov.htm Farkhad Kerimov]. Farkhad Kerimov was murdered while filming for the Associated Press behind rebel lines in Chechnya. No motive has ever been established for the killing. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20020124214713/http://www.cpj.org/attacks95/att95europe.html Natalya Alyakina], a free-lance correspondent for German news outlets, was shot dead in June by a soldier after clearing a Russian checkpoint near the southern Russian city of Budyonnovsk. *[http://www.cpj.org/killed/killed_archives/1995_list.html Shamkhan Kagirov], a reporter for the Moscow daily ''Rossiyskaya Gazeta'' and the local ''Vozrozhenie'' newspaper, was shot and killed in an ambush in Chechnya. Kagirov and three local police officers were traveling in a car near Grozny when they were attacked. The three officers were also killed. *11 March 1996 –{{anchor|Viktor Pimenov}}Viktor Pimenov, a cameraman with the local Vainakh TV company was fatally shot in the back by a sniper positioned on the roof of a 16-story building in Grozny. Pimenov had been filming the devastation caused to the Chechen capital by the 6–9 March rebel raid on the city. Pimenov was posthumously awarded the [[Rory Peck Award]].{{citation|url=https://rorypecktrust.org/getmedia/aee87118-5339-4121-af75-dee459267c30/Rory-Peck-Awards-Brochure-2009.pdf.aspx|title=The Rory Peck Awards 2009|accessdate=16 January 2016}} *20 March 1996 – [[Nadezhda Chaikova]], correspondent for the ''Obshchaya gazeta'' (Moscow) weekly newspaper disappeared while on assignment. Her body was found buried in the Chechen village of Gekhi on 11 April, blindfolded and showing signs of abuse. The cause of death was a gunshot wound to the back of the head. The identity of her executioners remains disputed. According to documents from [[Dzhokhar Dudaev|Dudaev's]] archive that came into the hands of Russian special services in 2002, she was killed by people from the so called "Department of state security of the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria" ({{lang-ru|Департамент государственной безопасности ЧРИ}}).[https://web.archive.org/web/20020704214517/http://www.vesti7.ru/archive/news?id=552 Боевики готовились к захвату атомной подлодки] (Вести недели, 10 February 2002) (Russian)[http://www.duel.ru/200519/?19_3_1 Путь в никуда (дружба с террористами к добру не ведет // "Дуэль", 17 мая 2005] (Russian) At the time there were strong suspicions that Russian security services were involved. === September 1996 to October 1999 === No journalists are recorded as having been killed between September 1996 and October 1999 but 22 were kidnapped during these three years and later released.{{cite web|url=http://www.russian-zona.spb.ru/centr.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912205712/http://www.russian-zona.spb.ru/centr.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2012|title=A dangerous occupation, CJES bulletin, 21 (123) 24-30 May 2004|publisher=Russian-zona.spb.ru|access-date=18 October 2014}} === 2nd Chechen war, 1999 onwards === A counter-terrorist operation by the federal authorities began in the region in September 1999. It was declared over on 16 April 2009. * 27–29 October 1999 – Journalist Supyan Ependiyev. On the evening of 27 October 1999, several short-range ballistic missiles hit a crowded outdoor market in central Grozny, killing and wounding hundreds of people. About an hour after the attack, Ependiyev went to the scene to cover the carnage for his paper. As he was leaving the site, a new round of rockets fell about 200 meters from the bazaar. Ependiyev suffered severe shrapnel wounds and died in a Grozny hospital the next morning. According to other sources, he died two days later. * 29 October 1999 – Cameramen [[Ramzan Mezhidov]] and Shamil Gigayev. The journalists were part of a civilian convoy, including Red Cross workers and vehicles, which was attempting to leave Chechnya. Turned back at the republic's eastern border, they were travelling along the highway from Grozny to Nazran in neighbouring Ingushetia when their vehicles came under attack. As the convoy approached Shami-Yurt, a Russian fighter fired several time from the air, hitting a busload of refugees. Mezhidov and Gigayev left their vehicle to film the carnage. As they approached the bus, another Russian rocket hit a nearby truck, fatally wounding both journalists. * 19 July 1999 – Photojournalist Vladimir Yatsina, an [[ITAR-TASS]] staff member freelancing on his only trip to Chechnya, was kidnapped and killed there by a group of [[Wahhabis]].{{cite web|url=http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGEUR460162000?open&of=ENG-2U4|title= Chechnya: Civilian hostages at risk |publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|author=|date=|website=Amnesty.org|access-date=15 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.library.cjes.ru/online/?a=con&b_id=1&c_id=267|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130113152253/http://www.library.cjes.ru/online/?a=con&b_id=1&c_id=267|deadurl=yes|title=Библиотека Центра экстремальной журналистики|author=|date=13 January 2013|archivedate=13 January 2013|website=CJES.ru|access-date=15 June 2017}} * 16 October 2000 – Antonio Russo,{{cite news|last1=Gentleman|first1=Amelia|last2=Carroll|first2=Rory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2000/nov/12/russia.ameliagentleman|title=Was reporter killed by Putin's secret service?|date=11 November 2000|publisher=|access-date=15 June 2017|via=The Guardian}} an Italian freelance journalist, was killed in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. His body was found near a Russian army base. He had come to the Georgian capital to document the Chechen conflict as a [[Radio Radicale]] reporter, working for a radio station belonging to the Italian Radical Party ([[Partito Radicale]]). His body displayed injuries caused by torture, probably from military techniques. None of the tapes, articles, and writings left in his Georgian apartment have been found. * Aleksandr Yefremov,{{cite web|url=http://www.cpj.org/news/2001/killed_release_01.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010409194314/http://www.cpj.org/news/2001/killed_release_01.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 April 2001|title=CPJ News Alert 2001|author=|date=9 April 2001|access-date=15 June 2017}} a [[photojournalist]] of the western Siberian newspaper ''Nashe Vremya'' was killed in Chechnya when rebels blew up a military jeep in which he was riding. On previous assignments, Yefremov had won acclaim for his news photographs from the war-torn region. * 26 September 2002 – Cameraman and editor [[Roddy Scott]] was killed in Ingushetia. Russian soldiers found his body in the republic's Galashki region, near the border with Chechnya, following a bloody battle between Russian forces and a group of Chechen fighters. * 15 July 2009 – Former teacher and TV journalist [[Natalia Estemirova]], now{{When|date=June 2017}} an award-winning Russian human rights activist, board member of the Russian NGO [[Memorial (society)|Memorial]], and author for ''Novaya gazeta'', was murdered and abducted.[http://www.hro.org/node/6071 Natalia Estemirova's biography] at Moscow-based Human Rights Online {{ru icon}} Estemirova was abducted around 8.30 am from outside her home in [[Grozny]], [[Chechnya]] as she was working on "extremely sensitive" cases of human rights abuses in Chechnya.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/5835198/Russian-activist-Natalia-Estemirova-found-dead.html Human rights worker abducted in Chechnya], [[Reuters]], reporting by Amie Ferris-Rotman and Aydar Buribayev, editing by Robin Pomeroy, 15 July 2009 Two witnesses reportedly saw Estemirova being pushed into a car, shouting that she was being abducted. She was found with bullet wounds in the head and chest at 4.30 pm in woodland {{convert|100|m|0|abbr=on}} away from the "Kavkaz" federal highway near the village of Gazi-Yurt, [[Ingushetia]].[http://newsru.com/russia/15jul2009/natalia.html A human rights defender who investigated murders and abductions was abducted in Grozny and found dead in Ingushetia], [[Newsru.com]], 15 July 2009 {{ru icon}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=ru&tl=en&u=http://newsru.com/russia/15jul2009/natalia.html computer translation]) * 1 August – Malika Betiyeva was killed on the Grozny-Shatoi highway. The deputy chief editor of ''Molodyozhnaya smena'' and Chechnya correspondent of the ''Dosh'' (Word) magazine died with four of her immediate family in a car crash.{{cite web|url=http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/federaldistrictplus:Chechnya |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819032825/http://journalists-in-russia.org/journalists/index/federaldistrictplus%3AChechnya |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 August 2011 |title=JOURNALISTS IN RUSSIA. An online database. Deaths and disappearances in Chechnya |publisher=Journalist-in-russia.org |access-date=18 October 2014 |df= }} ==See also== * [[Russian mafia]] * [[Crime in Russia]] * [[List of newspapers#Russia|List of newspapers in Russia]] * [[List of Russian-language television channels]] * [[Media freedom in Russia]] * [[List of journalists killed in Tajikistan]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{External links|date=June 2017}} * [http://www.gdf.ru/digest Glasnost Defence Foundation] * [http://www.cjes.ru/?lang=eng Center for Journalism in Extreme Situations] * [http://www.cpj.org/ Committee to Protect Journalists] * [http://www.ifj.org/ International Federation of Journalists] * [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0712/09/se.02.html Transcript of "Czar Putin", a CNN documentary investigating how many journalists have been killed in Russia since 1991] {{Asia topic|List of journalists killed in}} {{Europe topic|List of journalists killed in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Journalists Killed In Russia}} [[Category:Censorship in Russia]] [[Category:Journalists killed in Russia| ]] [[Category:Crime in Russia|Murder victims]] [[Category:Russian journalists| ]] [[Category:Human rights in Russia]] [[Category:Politics of Russia]] [[Category:Lists of journalists killed|Russia]] [[Category:Russia-related lists|Journalists]] [[Category:Russian political activists]] [[Category:Terrorism in Russia]] [[Category:Lists of Russian media]]

page.title: List of regional languages of the Philippines

revision.comment: Removing stale merge proposal from 2017; no case made, no support over more than a year
revision.text:
{{one source|date=April 2015}} This is the list of recognized regional languages in the Philippines as ordered and permitted by the [[Department of Education (Philippines)]] under the Mother Tongue-Based Multi-Lingual Education (MTB-MLE) strategy:<ref name="7 mother tongues">[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/317280/news/nation/deped-adds-7-languages-to-mother-tongue-based-education-for-kinder-to-grade-3 DepEd adds 7 languages to mother tongue-based education for Kinder to Grade 3]. [[GMA News]]. July 13, 2013.</ref>
● [[Aklan language|Aklanon]]
● [[Northern Alta language|Alta, Northern]]
● [[Southern Alta language|Alta, Southern]]
● [[Atta language|Atta]]
● [[Central Bikol language|Bikol]]
● [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]]
● [[Chavacano]]
● [[Ga'dang language|Ga'dang]]
● [[Gaddang language|Gaddang]]
● [[Hiligaynon language|Hiligaynon]]
● [[Ibaloy language|Ibaloy]]
● [[Ibanag language|Ibanag]]
● [[Ilocano language|Ilocano]]
● [[Isinai language|Isinai]]
● [[Isnag language|Isnag]]
● [[Itawis language|Itawis]]
● [[Itneg language|Itneg]]
● [[Ivatan language|Ivatan]]
● [[Kankanaey language|Kankanaey]]
● [[Kapampangan language|Kapampangan]]
● [[Kinaray-a language|Kinaray-a]]
● [[Central Cagayan Agta language|Labin Agta]]
● [[Maguindanao language|Maguindanao]]
● [[Manobo language|Manobo]]
● [[Maranao language|Maranao]]
● [[Pangasinan language|Pangasinan]]
● [[Sambal language|Sambal]]
● [[Surigaonon language|Surigaonon]]
● [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]
● [[Tausug language|Tausug]]
● [[Waray language|Waray]]
● [[Yakan language|Yakan]]
● [[Yogad language|Yogad]]
==Objective== The Philippines' [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Department of Education]] decided to implement the program starting school year 2012. The Mother Tongue is primarily taught at kindergarten and grades 1, 2 and 3. The adoption of regional languages as medium of teaching is based on studies which tend to show that using the mother tongue as the language of instruction in the classroom literacy among [[Filipino people|Filipino]]s bolster comprehension and critical thinking skills of Filipino children in the school and facilitate learning of second language such as English and the Philippines' national language called [[Filipino language|Filipino]]. Filipino is Tagalog-based which means that speakers of Tagalog are speakers of the Philippine national language.
==Other languages== There are approximately more than 175 languages and dialects in the Philippines which form part of the regional languages group. A few of these languages and dialects are spoken by in islands communities such as [[Abaknon language|Abaknon]] in [[Capul, Northern Samar|Capul]] island.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Languages of the Philippines}}
[[Category:Languages of the Philippines|#]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Regional languages of the Philippines}} {{Austronesian-lang-stub}} {{Philippines-stub}}
