revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Canada Population density map.jpg|thumb|Canada Population density map showing northern United States|400px]] [[File:Population Canada ver 4.png|thumb|400px|right| Historical population of Canada since confederation, 1867–2009]] [[Canada]] ranks [[List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population#Sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_population|38]] comprising about 0.5% of the world's total population,{{cite web|title=Environment — Greenhouse Gases (Greenhouse Gas Emissions per Person) |url=http://www4.hrsdc.gc.ca/.3ndic.1t.4r@-eng.jsp?iid=64|publisher=Human Resources and Skills Development Canada|year=2010|accessdate=23 June 2010}} with over '''37 million''' [[Canadians]] as of 2018.{{cite web |author=Statistics Canada |title=Population estimates quarterly |date=June 14, 2018|url=https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1710000901 |accessdate=June 14, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} Despite having the [[List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area#Countries_and_dependencies_by_area|2nd]] largest landmass, the vast majority of the country is sparsely inhabited, with most of its population south of the [[55th parallel north]]. Though Canada's [[List of countries and dependencies by population density|population density]] is low, many regions in the south such as [[Southern Ontario]], have population densities higher than several [[European countries]]. Canada's [[List_of_the_100_largest_population_centres_in_Canada#Lists|largest population centres]] are [[Toronto]], [[Montreal]], [[Vancouver]], [[Calgary]], [[Edmonton]] and [[Ottawa]] with those six being the only ones with more than one million people. The large size of Canada's north which is not [[Arable land|arable]], and thus cannot support large human populations, significantly lowers the [[carrying capacity]]. Therefore, the population density of the habitable land in Canada can be modest to high depending on the region. The historical growth of Canada's population is complex and has been influenced in many different ways, such as indigenous populations, expansion of territory, and human migration. Being a [[new world]] country, Canada has been predisposed to be a very open society with regards to [[Immigration to Canada|immigration]], which has been the most important factor in its historical population growth.{{cite web|url=http://www4.hrsdc.gc.ca/.3ndic.1t.4r@-eng.jsp?iid=35|title=Canadians in Context — Population Size and Growth |publisher=Human Resources and Skills Development Canada|year=2010|accessdate=17 December 2010}} The 2016 Canadian census counted a total population of '''35,151,728''', an increase of around 5.0 percent over the 2011 figure.{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/toronto-montreal-vancouver-now-home-to-one-third-of-canadians-census-1.3275666 |title=Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver now home to one-third of Canadians: census |last=Press |first=Jordan |date=February 8, 2017 |website=CTV News |publisher=Bell Media |access-date=February 8, 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/dp-pd/hlt-fst/pd-pl/Table.cfm?Lang=Eng&T=101&S=50&O=A |title=2016 Census: Population and dwelling counts |date=February 8, 2017 |publisher=Statistics Canada |accessdate=February 8, 2017}} Between 1990 and 2008, the population increased by 5.6 million, equivalent to 20.4 percent overall growth.{{cite web |url=http://oee.nrcan.gc.ca/publications/statistics/trends10/chapter3.cfm |title=Energy Efficiency Trends in Canada, 1990 to 2008 |publisher=Natural Resources Canada |date=2011 |accessdate= December 13, 2015}} ==Historical population overview== ===Indigenous peoples=== {{see also|Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas}} {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = National indigenous Populations
(2011 National Household Survey){{cite web|url=http://www4.hrsdc.gc.ca/.3ndic.1t.4r@-eng.jsp?iid=36 |title=Canadians in Context - Aboriginal Population |publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2014}} |label1 = [[First Nations]] |value1 = 61 |color1 = DodgerBlue |label2 = [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] |value2 = 32 |color2 = Gray |label3 = [[Inuit]] |value3 = 4 |color3 = MediumSeaGreen |label4 = Multiple and non-Canadian North American aboriginals |value4 = 3 }} Scholars vary on the estimated size of the [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|indigenous population]] in [[Territorial evolution of Canada|what is now Canada]] prior to colonization and on the effects of [[European colonization of the Americas|European contact]].{{cite book|author1=Michael R. Haines|author2=Richard H. Steckel|title=A Population History of North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPdgiysIVcgC&pg=PA12|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-49666-7|page=12}} During the late 15th century is estimated to have been between 200,000 and two million,{{cite book|author1=Michael R. Haines|author2=Richard H. Steckel|title=A Population History of North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPdgiysIVcgC&pg=PA13|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-49666-7|page=13}} with a figure of 500,000 currently accepted by Canada's Royal Commission on Aboriginal Health.{{cite book|author1=Garrick Alan Bailey|author2=William C ... Sturtevant|author3=Smithsonian Institution (U S )|title=Handbook Of North American Indians: Indians in Contemporary Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z1IwUbZqjTUC&pg=PA285|year=2008|publisher=Government Printing Office|isbn=978-0-16-080388-8|page=285}} Although not without conflict, [[Euro-Canadian|European Canadians]]' early interactions with First Nations and Inuit populations were relatively peaceful.{{cite book|author=David L. Preston|title=The Texture of Contact: European and Indian Settler Communities on the Frontiers of Iroquoia, 1667-1783|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L-9N6-6UCnoC&pg=PA43|year=2009|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=978-0-8032-2549-7|pages=43–44}} However repeated outbreaks of European [[infectious disease]]s such as [[influenza]], [[measles]] and [[smallpox]] (to which they had no natural immunity),{{cite book|author1=William G. Dean|author2=Geoffrey J. Matthews|title=Concise Historical Atlas of Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dw39BoD0-6cC&pg=PA2|year=1998|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-4203-3|page=2}} combined with other effects of European contact, resulted in a twenty-five percent to eighty percent indigenous population decrease post-contact.{{cite book|author1=Herbert C. Northcott|author2=Donna Marie Wilson|title=Dying And Death In Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p_pMVs53mzQC&pg=PA25|year=2008|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-55111-873-4|pages=25–27}} Roland G Robertson suggests that during the late 1630s, smallpox killed over half of the [[Wyandot people|Wyandot (Huron)]], who controlled most of the early [[North American fur trade]] in the area of [[New France]].{{cite book|author=R. G. Robertson|title=Rotting Face : Smallpox and the American Indian|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-EoEm_OO8RgC|year=2001|publisher=University of Nebraska|isbn=978-0-87004-497-7}} In 1871 there was an enumeration of the indigenous population within the limits of Canada at the time, showing a total of only 102,358 individuals. According to the [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 Canadian Census]], indigenous peoples ([[First Nations]] – 851,560, [[Inuit]] – 59,445 and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] – 451,795) numbered at 1,400,685, or 4.3% of the country's total population.{{cite web|title=Aboriginal Peoples in Canada: First Nations People, Métis and Inuit|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/as-sa/99-011-x/99-011-x2011001-eng.cfm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2012}} ===New France=== The European population grew slowly under French rule,{{cite book|author=David L. Preston|title=The Texture of Contact: European and Indian Settler Communities on the Frontiers of Iroquoia, 1667-1783|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L-9N6-6UCnoC&pg=PA43|year=2009|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=978-0-8032-2549-7|page=43}} thus remained relatively low as growth was largely achieved through natural births, rather than by immigration.{{cite book|author=John Powell|title=Encyclopedia of North American Immigration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VNCX6UsdZYkC&pg=PA203|year=2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1012-7|page=203}} Most of the French were farmers, and the rate of natural increase among the settlers themselves was very high.{{cite book|author1=Thomas F. McIlwraith|author2=Edward K. Muller|title=North America: The Historical Geography of a Changing Continent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fa--xLT_dRYC&pg=PA72|year=2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4616-3960-2|page=72}} The women had about 30 per cent more children than comparable women who remained in France. Yves Landry says, "Canadians had an exceptional diet for their time."{{cite book|author=Yves Landry|title=Fertility in France and New France: The Distinguishing Characteristics of Canadian Behavior in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries|jstor=1171305|year=1993|publisher=Université de Montréal|pages=577–592, quote p 586}} The [[1666 census of New France]] was the first census conducted in North America.{{cite web|title=North America's First Census|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/jtalon2-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2009|accessdate=23 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616060433/http://www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/jtalon2-eng.htm|archivedate=16 June 2012|df=dmy-all}} It was organized by [[Jean Talon]], the first [[Intendant of New France]], between 1665 and 1666. According to Talon's census there were 3,215 people in New France, comprising 538 separate families.{{cite web|title=Ttables of census data collected in 1665 and 1666 by Jean Talon|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/5200679-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2009|accessdate=23 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202195703/http://www.statcan.gc.ca/kits-trousses/5200679-eng.htm|archivedate=2 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} The census showed a great difference in the number of men at 2,034 versus 1,181 women. By the early 1700s the [[New France]] settlers were well established along the [[Saint Lawrence River]] and [[Nova Scotia peninsula#Historic name|Acadian Peninsula]] with a population around 15,000 to 16,000.{{cite web|title=Estimated population of Canada, 1605 to present|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4151287-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2009|accessdate=2010-08-26}} Mainly due to natural increase and modest immigration from [[Regions of France|Northwest France]] ([[Brittany]], [[Normandy]], [[Île-de-France]], [[Poitou-Charentes]] and [[Pays de la Loire]]) the population of New France increased to 55,000 according to the last French census of 1754.{{cite book|author=Peter M. Leslie|title=Ethnonationalism in a Federal State: The Case of Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H7NXifhZKfgC&pg=PA6|year=1988|publisher=Queen's University|isbn=978-0-88911-456-2|page=6 note 5}} This was an increase from 42,701 in 1730.{{cite book|author=Louis Hartz|title=The Founding of New Societies: Studies in the History of the United States, Latin America, South Africa, Canada, and Australia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e7YFyzsBYnEC&pg=PT231|year=1969|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=0-547-97109-5|page=231}} ===British Canada=== [[File:Distribution of Population, 1851 to 1941.jpg|340px|thumb|Distribution of the population in Canada for the years 1851, 1871, 1901, 1921 and 1941]] During the late 18th and early 19th century [[Canada under British rule]] experienced strong population growth. In the wake of the [[Invasion of Canada (1775)|1775 invasion of Canada]] by the newly formed [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]], approximately 50,000 of the 70,000 [[United Empire Loyalists]] fled to [[British North America]], a large portion of whom migrated to Nova Scotia and [[New Brunswick]] (separated from Nova Scotia) in 1784: 20,000 to Nova Scotia and 14,000 to New Brunswick. The remainder went to England and the Caribbean. An additional 30,000 Americans, called "Late Loyalists," were lured into Ontario in the 1790s by the promise of land and swearing loyalty to the Crown.{{cite book|author1=John M. Murrin|author2=Paul E. Johnson|author3=James M. McPherson |author4=Gary Gerstle |author5=Emily S. Rosenberg|title=Liberty, Equality, Power, A History of the American People: To 1877|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hlyz-YK4oG8C&pg=PA172|year=2008|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-495-56634-2|page=172}} As a result of the period knows as the [[Great Migration of Canada|Great Migration]] by 1831, [[Lower Canada]]'s population had reached approximately 553,000, with [[Upper Canada]] reaching about 237,000 individuals.{{cite book|author1=Elisée Reclus|author2=Ernest George Ravenstein|author3=Augustus Henry Keane|title=The Earth and Its Inhabitants ...: British North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZQM_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA479|year=1893|publisher=D. Appleton|page=479}} The [[Irish Potato Famine]] of the 1840s had significantly increased the pace of Irish immigration to [[Prince Edward Island]] and the [[Province of Canada]], peaking in 1847 with 100,000 distressed individuals.{{cite book|author=Donald MacKay|title=Flight from Famine: The Coming of the Irish to Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M1tVIoSY7IYC&pg=PA13|year=2009|publisher=Dundurn|isbn=978-1-77070-506-7|page=13}} By 1851, the population of the [[The Maritimes|Maritime colonies]] also reached roughly 533,000 (277,000 in [[Nova Scotia]], 194,000 in New Brunswick and 62,000 in Prince Edward Island).{{cite book|author=Kenneth J. Rea|title=A guide to Canadian economic history|year=1991|publisher=Canadian Scholars' Press|isbn=978-0-921627-81-4|pages=64–65}} To the west [[British Columbia]] had about 55,000 individuals by 1851. Beginning in the late 1850s, the immigration of [[Chinese people|Chinese]] into the [[Colony of Vancouver Island]] and [[Colony of British Columbia]] peaked with the onset of the [[Fraser Canyon Gold Rush]].{{cite book|author1=Patricia Wong Wong Hall|author2=Hwang, Victor M.|title=Anti-Asian Violence in North America: Asian American and Asian Canadian Reflections on Hate, Healing, and Resistance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdfX7UCyDuQC&pg=PA9|year=2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-0459-2|page=9}} By 1861, as a result of natural births and the [[Great Migration of Canada]] from the [[British Isles]], the [[Province of Canada]] population increased to 3.1 million inhabitants. [[Newfoundland]]'s population by 1861 reached approximately 125,000 individuals. ===Post-confederation=== The population has increased every year since the establishment of the [[Canada|Dominion of Canada]] in 1867; however, the population of Newfoundland was not included prior to its entry into confederation as Canada's tenth province in 1949.{{cite web|title=Estimated population of Canada, 1605 to present|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4151287-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2009|accessdate=16 April 2010}} The first national census of the country was taken in 1871, with a population count around 3,689,000.{{cite web|title=History of the Census of Canada|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/Info/history.cfm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2006|accessdate=22 June 2010}} The year with the least population growth (in real terms) was 1882–1883, when only 30,000 new individuals were enumerated. [[File:Canada immigration graph.png|thumb|340px|Births and immigration in Canada from 1850 to 2000]] The [[Canada 1911 Census|1911 census]] was a detailed enumeration of the population showing a count of 7,206,643 individuals.{{cite web|title=OGSPI 1911 Census Menu|url=http://www.ogs.on.ca/ogspi/1/1.htm|publisher=The Ontario Genealogical Society (OGS)|year=2005|accessdate=23 June 2010}} This was an increase of 34% over the [[Canada 1901 Census|1901 census]] of 5,371,315.{{cite web|title=Canadian Immigration – Early 1900s|url=http://www.british-immigrants-in-montreal.com/canadian-immigration-early-1900s.html|publisher=British immigrants in Montreal|year=2010|accessdate=24 June 2010}} The year with the most population growth was during the peak of the [[Post-World War II baby boom]] in 1956–1957, when the population grew by over 529,000, in a single twelve-month period. The Canadian baby boom, defined as the period from 1947 to 1966, saw more than 400,000 babies born annually.{{cite news|title=By definition: Boom, bust, X and why|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060623.dates24/BNStory/BabyBoomers/home|publisher=Globe and Mail|date=2006–2009|accessdate=23 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520180757/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060623.dates24/BNStory/BabyBoomers/home|archivedate=20 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} The [[Canada 1996 Census|1996 census]] recorded a total population of 28,846,761.{{cite web|title=Census of Canada, A population and dwelling counts|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/970415/dq970415-eng.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=1997|accessdate=22 June 2010}} This was a 5.7% increase over the [[Canada 1991 Census|1991 census]] of 27,296,859. The [[Canada 2001 Census|2001 census]] had a total population count of 30,007,094.{{cite web|title=2001 Census facts: did you know...|url=http://www.cfc-fcc.ca/doc/whatsnew_docs/N_1_06_E_InformationSheet.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2006|accessdate=24 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706172504/http://www.cfc-fcc.ca/doc/whatsnew_docs/N_1_06_E_InformationSheet.pdf|archivedate=6 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} In contrast, the official [[Statistics Canada]] population estimate for 2001 was 31,021,300.{{cite web|title=Population estimates|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/010925/dq010925a-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2006|accessdate=24 June 2010}} Canada's total population enumerated by the [[Canada 2006 Census|2006 census]] was 31,612,897. This count was lower than the official 1 July 2006 population estimate of 32,623,490 people.{{cite web|title=Differences between Statistics Canada’s census counts and population estimates|url=http://www.gov.nu.ca/eia/stats/Cenvsest/cenvsest.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2006|accessdate=22 June 2010}} Ninety-percent of the population growth between 2001 and 2006 was concentrated in the [[List of the 100 largest metropolitan areas in Canada|main metropolitan areas]].{{cite web|title=Population and dwelling counts A portrait of the Canadian population|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/census-recensement/2006/rt-td/pd-pl-eng.cfm|publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2007|accessdate=22 June 2010}} The [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 census]] was the fifteenth decennial census with a total population count of 33,476,688 up 5.9% from 2006. On average, censuses have been taken every five years since 1905. Censuses are required to be taken at least every ten years as mandated in section 8 of the [[Constitution Act, 1867]].{{cite web|url=http://www.solon.org/Constitutions/Canada/English/ca_1867.html|title=The Constitution Act, 1867|publisher=The Solon Law Archive|year=2001|accessdate=23 June 2010}} ==Components of population growth== [[File:Population of Canada by Province and Territory (July 2013).png|thumb|Population of Canada broken out by Province and Territory as of July 2013]] In 2010, Canada's annual [[population growth rate]] was 1.238%, or a daily increase of 1,137 individuals.{{cite web|title=Canadians in Context — Population Size and Growth|url=http://www4.hrsdc.gc.ca/.3ndic.1t.4r@-eng.jsp?iid=35|publisher=Human Resources and Skills Development Canada|year=2010|accessdate=23 June 2010}} Between 1867 and 2009 Canada's population grew by 979%. Canada had the highest net migration rate (0.61%) of all [[G8|G-8 member countries]] between 1994 and 2004. Natural growth accounts for an annual increase of 137,626 persons, at a yearly rate of 0.413%. Between 2001 and 2006, there were 1,446,080 [[Immigration to Canada|immigrants]] and 237,418 emigrants, resulting in a net migration of just over 1.2 million people. Since 2001, immigration has ranged between 221,352 and 262,236 immigrants per annum.{{cite web|url=http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/statistics/menu-fact.asp |title=Immigration overview – Permanent and temporary residents|publisher= [[Citizenship and Immigration Canada]]|accessdate=February 11, 2014|year=2012}} {{-}} ==Population by years == Prior to [[Canadian confederation]] in 1867 the population counts reflected only the [[Former colonies and territories in Canada|former colonies and settlements]] and not the country to be as a whole with indigenous nations separated.{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4198820-eng.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Statistics of Canada|title=Summaries of census information from 1605 to 1871|year=2008|accessdate=20 July 2010}} ===Ephemeral European settlements=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Area/colony ! scope="col" |Population ! scope="col" | Notes{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4151281-eng.htm |title=Censuses of Canada 1665 to 1871: Early exploration (16th century) |publisher=Statcan.gc.ca |year=2013 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}} |- |1000|| [[L'Anse aux Meadows|L'Anse aux Meadows
(Newfoundland)]]||30 to 160||Archaeological evidence of a short-lived [[Norse colonization of the Americas|Norse settlement]] was found a L'Anse aux Meadows, on the northernmost tip of the island of Newfoundland ([[Radiocarbon dating|carbon dating]] estimate 990–1050 AD.{{cite book|author1=Linda S. Cordell|author2=Kent Lightfoot|author3=Francis McManamon|author4=George Milner|title=Archaeology in America: An Encyclopedia: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arfWRW5OFVgC&pg=PA82|date=30 December 2008|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-02189-3|pages=82–}}) There is no record of how many men and women lived at the site at any given time, however archaeological evidence of the dwellings suggest it had the capacity of supporting 30 to 160 individuals.{{cite book|author=Annette Kolodny|title=In Search of First Contact: The Vikings of Vinland, the Peoples of the Dawnland, and the Anglo-American Anxiety of Discovery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B2qpdOb8o4cC&pg=PA95|year=2012|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-5286-9|page=95}} |- |1541|| [[Cap-Rouge, Quebec City|Cap-Rouge
(Quebec City)]]||400 ||[[Jacques Cartier]] established Charlesbourg-Royal at Cap-Rouge on his third voyage. Even though scurvy was cured through the indigenous remedy ([[Thuja occidentalis#Uses|Thuja occidentalis infusion]]), the impression left is of a general misery with the effort being abandoned.{{cite book|author1=Conrad Heidenreich|author2=K. Janet Ritch|title=Samuel de Champlain Before 1604: Des Sauvages and Other Documents Related to the Period|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G2D1py50xZ4C&pg=PA43|year=2010|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-3757-6|pages=43–44}} During the winter 35 of Cartier's men perished. |- |1543|| Cap-Rouge
(Quebec City)||200 ||In 1542, [[Jean-François Roberval]] tried to re-invigorate the Charlesbourg-Royal colony at Cap-Rouge which Roberval renamed France-Roy, however after a set of disastrous winters the effort was abandoned.{{cite book|author=Rene Chartrand|title=The Forts of New France in Northeast America 1600-1763|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=njiVxEIVM0AC&pg=PA8|year=2008|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-84603-255-4|page=8}} En route to Charlesbourg-Royal, Roberval had abandoned his near-relative [[Marguerite de La Rocque]] with her lover on the "Isle of Demons" (now called [[Harrington Harbour, Quebec|Harrington Island]]), in the [[Gulf of Saint Lawrence]], as punishment for their affair. The young man, their servant and baby died, but Marguerite survived to be rescued by fishermen and returned to France two years later.{{cite book|author=Alan Gordon|title=The Hero and the Historians: Historiography and the Uses of Jacques Cartier|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jZhdAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA23|year=2010|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-5920-2|page=23}} |- |1583|| [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John Bay
(Newfoundland)]]||260||[[Humphrey Gilbert]] with 260 men planned a settlement; however, during exploration of the coast line a ship was lost containing many of the prospective colonists and their provisions.{{cite book|author=Britannica Educational Publishing|title=From Columbus to Colonial America: 1492 to 1763|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qeycAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA7|year=2011|publisher=Britannica Educational Publishing|isbn=978-1-61530-734-0|page=7}} |- |1598|| [[Sable Island|Sable Island
(Nova Scotia)]] ||50 || Marquis de La Roche-Mesgouez and 40 convicts (peasants and beggars) with 10 soldiers settled on Sable Island, but this colonization attempt failed, culminating in a revolt with only 11 survivors evacuated.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmhg.gc.ca/cmh/page-28-eng.asp |title=Canadian Military Heritage |publisher=Cmhg.gc.ca |year=2011 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}} |- |1600 || [[Tadoussac, Quebec|Tadoussac
(Quebec)]]|| 16 ||[[François Gravé Du Pont]] with 16 men built a fur trading post at Tadoussac; however, only five of the men survived the winter before returning to France.{{cite book|author=Roger E. Riendeau|title=A Brief History of Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CFWy0EfzlX0C&pg=PA36|year=2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0822-3|page=36}} |- |1604|| [[Saint Croix Island, Maine|Saint Croix
(Maine)]] || 79 ||The [[Saint Croix Island, Maine#St. Croix Settlement|St. Croix settlement of Maine]] was the first real attempt at a year-round base of operation in [[New France]]. The expedition was led by [[Pierre Du Gua de Monts]] with 79 settlers including François Gravé Du Pont, Royal cartographer [[Samuel de Champlain]], the [[Jean de Biencourt de Poutrincourt et de Saint-Just|Baron de Poutrincourt]], apothecary [[Louis Hébert]], a priest [[Nicolas Aubry]], and [[Mathieu de Costa]] a linguist.{{cite book|author=John G. Reid|title=The "conquest" of Acadia, 1710: Imperial, Colonial, and Aboriginal Constructions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MqJ9qFqWK4IC&pg=PA32|year=2004|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-8538-2|page=32}} The St. Croix settlement was abandoned the following summer for a new [[habitation at Port-Royal]] after 35 died of scurvy. |} ===Former colonies and territories === ==== 17th century ==== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Area/colony ! scope="col" | Population {{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4064812-eng.htm |title=Censuses of Canada 1665 to 1871: Early French settlements (1605 to 1691) |publisher=Statistics Canada|year=2008 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4151280-eng.htm |title=Censuses of Canada 1665 to 1871: Early English settlements (1692 to 1749) |publisher=Statistics Canada |year=2008 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}} ! scope="col" | Notes |- | 1605 || [[Port Royal, Annapolis County, Nova Scotia|Port Royal
(Nova Scotia)]] || 44 ||The 44 colonists are surviving members of 79 from the now abandoned St. Croix settlement of Maine. However, the [[habitation at Port-Royal]] was also abandoned and left in the care of the local [[Mi'kmaq]].{{cite book|author=Harald E. L. Prins|title=The Miʼkmaq: resistance, accommodation, and cultural survival|year=1996|publisher=Harcourt Brace College Pub.|isbn=978-0-03-053427-0|page=61}} The settlement was later moved upstream and to the south bank of the Annapolis River, keeping the name [[Port-Royal (Acadia)|Port-Royal]] and becoming the capital of [[Acadia]].{{cite book|author=Spencer C. Tucker|title=Almanac of American Military History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TO2mx314ST0C&pg=PA69|year=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-530-3|page=69}} |- | 1608 ||[[History of Quebec City#French rule|Quebec City]] || 28 ||[[Samuel de Champlain]] establishes the colony with 28 settlers. Half of the men that winter the first year die of scurvy or starvation.{{cite book|author=Ruben C. Bellan|title=Canada's Cities: A History|year=2003|publisher=Whitefield Press|isbn=978-0-9699686-1-0|page=2}} Nevertheless, new settlers arrive resulting in Quebec being the first permanent settlement, and also the capital of, the French colony of [[Canada (New France)|Canada]]. |- |1610 || [[Cuper's Cove, Newfoundland and Labrador|Cuper's Cove
(Newfoundland)]] ||40 ||The [[Newfoundland Colony]] is established by [[John Guy (governor)|John Guy]] his brother Phillip and his brother-in-law [[William Colston]] with 39 colonists who spend the winter of 1610–1611 at Cuper's Cove.{{cite book|author1=Andrew Ross|author2=Andrew Smith|title=Canada's Entrepreneurs: From The Fur Trade to the 1929 Stock Market Crash: Portraits from the Dictionary of Canadian Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EqpAnILPISoC&pg=PT24|year=2011|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-6254-4|page=24}} By the fall of 1613 sixteen structures are completed by about 60 settlers on the site.{{cite book|author1=Shannon Lewis-Simpson|author2=Peter E. Pope|title=Exploring Atlantic Transitions: Archaeologies of Transience and Permanence in New Found Lands|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gagTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA62|year=2013|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=978-1-84383-859-3|page=62}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=13827 |title=The Governor General of Canada > 400th Anniversary of the town of Cupids |publisher=Gg.ca |date=2010-08-17 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}} As England tried to create a foothold in the north, other settlements were established at [[Subdivision 1I, Newfoundland and Labrador#Bristol's Hope|Bristol's Hope]], [[Renews]], [[New Cambriol]], [[South Falkland]] and [[Province of Avalon|Avalon]], an area that became known as the English Shore. However the majority of the population did not stay year round returning in the spring of each year. Over the next 100 years the English colonies of Newfoundland grew very slowly, and had only 3,000 permanent residents by the 1720s.{{cite book|author=Jerry Bannister|title=The Rule of the Admirals: Law, Custom, and Naval Government in Newfoundland, 1699-1832|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0Uqic0VhFwC&pg=PA8|year=2003|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-8613-6|page=8}} |- |1629 || Quebec city || 117 ||90 wintering belonged to [[David Kirke|Kirke's English Expedition]] that had captured the city.{{cite book|title=Census of Canada 1851/52-|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ssYzAQAAMAAJ&pg=PR16|year=1876|publisher=Des presses a Vapeur de Lovell et Lamoureaux|page=16}} Under brief British control the city begins to grow and be fortified. Prior to 1632 only eight births were recorded among the 60 to 70 permanent European settlers.{{cite book|author1=Michael R. Haines|author2=Richard H. Steckel|title=A Population History of North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPdgiysIVcgC&pg=PA104|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-49666-7|page=104}} The first European child born in Quebec had been [[Hélène Desportes]], in 1620.{{cite book|author=Raymonde Litalien|title=Champlain: The Birth of French America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZnE0tjj9MbgC&pg=PA368|year= 2004|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press |isbn=978-0-7735-7256-0|page=368}} |- |1641 || [[New France]] || 240 ||De facto population of Canada (New France) and Acadia, now situated partly in the future United States.{{cite book|author=Canada. Dept. of Public Works|title=Annual Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SCQAAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA3-PA8|year=1891|pages=3–}} |- |1642 || [[Fort Ville-Marie]]
([[Old Montreal]]) || 50 ||New colony with the majority of immigrants coming directly from France led by [[Paul de Chomedey, Sieur de Maisonneuve|Paul de Chomedey]] and [[Jeanne Mance]], a lay woman.{{cite book|author=Terence J. Fay|title=History of Canadian Catholics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4OszB8KwdjgC&pg=PA17|year=2002|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-2313-5|page=17}} |- |1666 || Canada (New France) || 3,215 ||The 1660s marked the only real "wave" of French settlers arriving until the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] in 1713.{{cite book|author=James Pritchard|title=In Search of Empire: The French in the Americas, 1670-1730|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kK9wa98I4eEC&pg=PA24|year=2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-82742-3|page=24}} Following the initial wave of French settlers natural growth was the main contributing factor to population growth. Quebec city 2,100, [[Trois-Rivieres]] 455, Montreal 655. (Comprising 528 families with 2,034 men and 1,181 women. Professionals included 3 notaries, 3 schoolmasters, 3 locksmiths, 4 bailiffs, 5 surgeons, 5 bakers, 8 barrel makers, 9 millers, 18 official merchants, 27 joiners, and 36 carpenters.) |- |1677|| [[Classification of indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous
Nations]]|| 10,750||Estimated indigenous population in and around New France territory 10,750, including 2,150 warriors. ([[Mohawk people|Mohawks]] 5 villages, 96 lodges, 300 warriors - [[Oneida people|Oneidas]] 1 village, 100 lodges, 200 warriors - [[Onondaga people|Onondagas]] 2 villages, 164 lodges, 350 warriors - [[Cayugas]] 3 villages, 100 lodges, 300 warriors - [[Seneca people|Senecas]] 4 villages, 324 lodges, 1,000 warriors). |- |1679 || Acadia || 515|| Majority are from the [[Poitou]] region of France. |- |1681 || New France || 9,677 ||New France sees new settlements develop as residents leave Quebec City (population 1,345) and Trois-Rivières (150) with Montreal gaining influence (population 1,418). |- |1687 || [[Newfoundland]] || 663 ||French population only. |- |1695 ||New France || 13,639 ||Population of [[Saint John River (Bay of Fundy)|Saint John River New Brunswick]] 49. |- |1698 || New France || 15,355 ||English population of Newfoundland at the time 1,500. |} ====18th century==== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Area/colony ! scope="col" | Population {{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/98-187-x/4151286-eng.htm |title=Censuses of Canada 1665 to 1871: Upper Canada & Loyalists (1785 to 1797) |publisher=Statistics Canada |year=2008 |accessdate=2 Feb 2014}} ! scope="col" | Notes |- |1705 || Newfoundland || 520 ||French population only |- |1706 || New France || 16,417||Covering territory that is now situated partly in the United States of America and partly in Canada. |- |1712 || New France ||18,440 ||Married - men 2,786, women 2,588. Unmarried - males 6,716, females 6,350. |- |1718 || New France || 22,983 ||Married - men 3,662, women 3,926. Unmarried - males 7,911, females 7,484. |- |1720 ||St.John Island
([[Prince Edward Island]]) || 100 ||17 families |- |1730 ||New France || 33,682 ||Married - men 6,050, women 5,728. Unmarried - males 11,314, females 10,590. |- |1736 ||Indigenous

Unmarried - males 13,330, females 12,458. |- |1741 || Newfoundland || 6,000 ||English population only. |- | 1749 || [[Nova Scotia]] || 2,544 ||Married - men, 509 ; women 509. ([[Cape Breton Regional Municipality|Cape Breton]]) || 1,000 ||French population only. |- |1749|| Acadian Mainland ([[New Brunswick]]) || 1,000 ||French population only. |- |1749 ||[[Nova Scotia peninsula#Historic name|Acadian Peninsula]]||13,000||French population only. |- |1749|| St. John Island

Children boys, 1,899 ; children girls, 1,123. |- |1760||New France ||70,000||[[Expulsion of the Acadians]] three-quarters of the Acadian population of 18,000 forcibly relocated between 1755 and 1764.{{cite book|author1=Rocío G. Davis|author2=Rosalía Baena|title=Tricks with a Glass: Writing Ethnicity in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ovgTStFuX_sC&pg=PA113|year=2000|publisher=[[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]]|isbn=90-420-1213-7|page=113}} |- |1765 || [[Province of Quebec (1763–91)]] || 69,810|| French and English populations. |- |1775 || Province of Quebec (1763–91) || 90,000||French and English populations. |- |1785 || Newfoundland || 10,244||French and English populations. |- |1790 || Nova Scotia || 30,000||French and English populations. |- |1797 || St. John Island

Steckel|title=A Population History of North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPdgiysIVcgC&pg=PP1|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-49666-7}} *{{cite book|author=Alan Simmons|title=Immigration and Canada: Global and Transnational Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K0YwAJ7MpswC&pg=PP1|year=2010|publisher=Canadian Scholars’ Press|isbn=978-1-55130-362-8}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Demographics of Canada}} *[https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/180614/dq180614c-eng.htm Population of Canada] - The Daily (Statistics Canada) *[http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/canada-population/ Canada Population] – Worldometers *[http://www.stats.gov.nl.ca/statistics/population/PDF/Annual_Pop_Prov.PDF Annual Estimates of Population for Canada, Provinces and Territories, from July 1, 1971 to July 1, 2014] - Economics and Statistics Branch (Newfoundland & Labrador Statistics Agency) *[http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2011/dp-pd/hlt-fst/pd-pl/index-eng.cfm Population and Dwelling Count, 2011 Census] – Statistics Canada *[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/tables-tableaux/sum-som/l01/cst01/demo23a-eng.htm Population estimates and projections, 2010 – 2036] – Statistics Canada *[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/11-516-x/sectiona/4147436-eng.htm Historical population and migration statistical data] – Statistics Canada (Archived) *[http://www.populationinstituteofcanada.ca/ Population Institute of Canada] {{Navboxes | title = [[File:Maple Leaf (from roundel).svg|20x20px|link=|alt=]] Links related to Canada and New France | titlestyle = color:black; background-color:white; | list1 = {{Canada topics}} {{New France}} {{Canada year nav}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Population Of Canada By Years}} [[Category:Demographics of Canada]]

{{dablink|This page is about the racial classification of Americans with ancestry from India, as viewed by U.S. courts, agencies, institutions, and self-identification. For anthropological racial classifications of Indians in general, see [[Racial groups of India]].}} {|class="infobox bordered" style="width: 290px; font-size: 95%; float: right;" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" |- | colspan="5" align="center" cellspacing="0" |
Racial classification of Indian** immigrants by the U.S. judiciary{{cite book|last=Lopez|first=Ian Haney|title=White By Law: The Legal Construction of Race|publisher=New York University Press|year=1996|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxYqorjC4gUC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}White by Law: How the U.S. Courts Established the White Race (Excerpted from White By Law). (2015). Model Minority. Retrieved November 1, 2015, from [http://modelminority.com/joomla/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=284:how-the-us-courts-established-the-white-race-&catid=42:law&Itemid=56 link]
|- | align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;" | Year | align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;" | Case | align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;" | Judgment | align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;" | Rationale | align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;" | Applicant's Ethnicity |- |1909 | In [[Bhicaji Balsara]] || white|| congressional intent||[[Parsi]] |- | 1910 | U.S. v. Dolla || White** || Ocular inspection of skin||[[Afghan]] born in IndiaBanks, T.L. (1998). [http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/aalj/vol5/iss1/2/ Both Edges of the Margin: Blacks and Asians in Mississippi Masala, Barriers to Coalition Building]. In Asian American Law Journal. Volume 5. Article 2. pp. 19 - 22. |- | 1910 | U.S. v. [[Bhicaji Balsara]] ||White || scientific evidence, congressional intent||[[Parsi]] |- | 1913 | In re [[A. K. Mozumdar|Akhay Kumar Mozumdar]] || White || legal precedent||"high-caste" [[North India]]n "Aryan"Howard, D. (2006). A.K. Mozumdar. Yesterday's Evangelist from India. Retrieved on October 31, 2015, from [http://www.mozumdar.org/yesterdaysevangelist.html link] |- | 1917 | In re Sadar Bhagwab Singh || not White || common knowledge, congressional intent||"Hindu",The Federal Reporter: with key number annotations. Volume 246. (1918). St. Paul: West Publishing, Co. pp. 500. no reference to caste |- | 1919 | In re Mohan Singh || White || scientific evidence, legal precedent||"high caste Hindu" "Aryan"The Federal Reporter: With Key-Number Annotations. Volume 257. (1919). St. Paul: West Publishing, Co. pp. 209 & 212. |- | 1920 | In re Thind || White || legal precedence||"high caste Hindu", born in [[Punjab region|Punjab]] |- | 1923 | [[United States v. Bhagat Singh Thind|U.S. v. Thind]] || not White || common knowledge, congressional intent||"high caste Hindu", born in PunjabUnited States v. Thind. (2015). Casetext.Retrieved November 1, 2015, from [https://casetext.com/case/united-states-v-thind link] |- | 1923 | U.S. v. Akhay Kumar Mozumdar || not White || legal precedent||"high-caste" North Indian "Aryan" |- | 1925 | U.S. v. Ali || not White*** || common knowledge||"[[Arabs in India|Arabian]]" from the [[Punjab region|Punjab]]United States v. Ali. (2015). Casetext. Retrieved October 31, 2015, from [https://casetext.com/case/united-states-v-ali link] |- | 1928 | U.S. v. Gokhale || not White || legal precedent||"[[Indo-Aryan peoples|Aryan]] Hindu of high caste"United States v. Gokhale. (2015). Casetext. Retrieved October 31, 2015, from [https://casetext.com/case/united-states-v-gokhale link]. |- | 1939 | Wadia v. U.S. || not White || common knowledge||[[Parsi]]Wadia v. United States. (2015). Casetext. Retrieved October 31, 2015, from [https://casetext.com/case/wadia-v-united-states link]. |- | 1942 | Kharaiti Ram Samras v. U.S. || not White|| legal precedent||born in [[Manko (village)|Manko]], [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab]], IndiaKharaiti Ram Samras v. United States. (2015). Casetext. Retrieved October 31, 2015, from [https://casetext.com/case/kharaiti-ram-samras-v-united-states link]. |- | colspan="5" | ** Court opinions and decisions on the racial classification of Asian Indians. Visual Inspection of skin of Mixed race, Caucasian and Native Indian. |- | colspan="5" | *** 1925 decision ruled specifically against [[Punjabis]] while other rulings were generally regarding all Indians, which is understood to have meant all those originally from South Asia. |} The '''[[Race (classification of human beings)|racial classification]] of [[Indian American]]s''' has varied over the years and across institutions.Harpalani, Vinay, DesiCrit: Theorizing the Racial Ambiguity of South Asian Americans (August 12, 2013). 69 NYU Annual Survey of American Law 77 (2013); Chicago-Kent College of Law Research Paper No. 2013-30. pp. 123, 124 & 136. Available at SSRN: [http://ssrn.com/abstract=2308892 link] Originally, neither the courts nor the census bureau classified Indian Americans as a race because there were only negligible numbers of Indian immigrants in the United States. Various court judgements instead deemed Indians to be "White" or "not White" for the purposes of law. In 1970, in the most recent assignment, the [[U.S. Census Bureau]] designated Asian Indians as [[white people|White.]]{{cite journal|last1=Espiritu|first1=Yen|title=Asian American Panethnicity: Bridging Institutions and Identities.|journal=American Journal of Sociology|date=1993|volume=99|issue=3|pages=796–798|jstor=2781307}} Since 1980, while keeping the validity of its earlier designation ([[white people|White]]), the U.S. Census Bureau further allowed Indian Americans to self-report their ethnicity, owing to the immense diversity of the Indian subcontinent, which is home to more than 2000 different ethnic groups{{cite web|title=Background Note: India|author=US Department of State|date=17 April 2012|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3454.htm}} and all the racial groups known to mankind.Bhasin, M.K. [http://nsdl.niscair.res.in/jspui/bitstream/123456789/339/1/pdf%204.4%20NISCAIR-Racial-Ethnic-Relgious-Linguistic-Groups-India-Text-Revised.pdf Racial, Ethnic, Religious and Linguistic Elements in Indian Population] Only the continent of [[Africa]] exceeds the linguistic, genetic and cultural diversity of the nation of India.[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/India.pdf India, a Country Study] ''United States Library of Congress, Note on Ethnic groups'' The decision to let Indian Americans self-identify was made both in light of the aforementioned diversity in India, which has all the different racial groups represented in its diverse population, in addition to accommodate the fact that in recent years, increasingly diverse racial and ethnic groups of Indians and South Asians have immigrated to the United States, including from the North-West of the Indian subcontinent, where [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]] ethnic groups are found. ==Initial perceptions== The earliest Indian immigrants into the United States were called "Hindoos" even though the majority of them were [[Sikh]]s. Court clerks classified these early immigrants from the [[Punjab region]] as being "white", "brown" or "black" based on their skin color for the purpose of marriage licenses. In addition to being [[Racialization|racialized]] by their color, they were also racialized as being "[[Ingroups and outgroups|foreigners]]". The perception of Indian Americans as foreigners, on the other hand, often helped provide for better treatment, especially in states where [[de jure]] segregation was in place. Regardless of their skin color, as "foreign internationals," Indians most often used 'White-Only' facilities, a privilege which they would not have been granted otherwise. As opposed to being seen as "negro," or "brown," they were seen as outside of the traditional American racial spectrum, and consequently freed from some of the encumbrances that system entailed.{{cite news|last1=New York Times|title=Negro Pastor Traveled in the South in Turban|url=http://i.imgur.com/GhmDWUk.jpg|accessdate=17 March 2016|agency=New York Times}}{{cite web|last1=Clerk|first1=Cecil|title=AskHistorians: How were Asians and Indians treated during times of racial segregation?|url=https://redd.it/2wrimw|website=Reddit|publisher=Reddit}}{{cite web|last1=Desai|first1=Manan|title=The 'Tan Stranger' from Ceylon|url=https://www.saada.org/tides/article/20140708-3618|website=South Asian American Digital Archive|publisher=SAADA|accessdate=17 March 2016}} ==U.S. courts== Throughout much of the 20th century, U.S. courts classified Indians as both [[white people|"White"]] and "non-White". Each ruling was for individuals from different ethnic and racial groups of the subcontinent, reflecting the variability in the resulting decisions. In 1909, [[Bhicaji Balsara]] became the first Indian to gain U.S. citizenship, as a [[Parsi]] he was ruled to be "the purest of Aryan type" and "as distinct from Hindus as are the English who dwell in India”. Almost thirty years later, the same Circuit Court to accept Balsara ruled that [[Rustom Dadabhoy Wadia]], another Parsi also from [[Bombay]] was not white and thefore not eligible to receive U.S. citizenship.{{cite book|title=Postmodernism & a Sociology...(c)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CnMon2RiFLAC&pg=PA143|publisher=University of Arkansas Press|isbn=978-1-61075-322-7|pages=143–}} In 1923, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] decided in ''[[United States v. Bhagat Singh Thind]]'' that while Indians were [[Caucasian race|Caucasians]] and that anthropologists considered them to be of the same race as [[white people|"White"]] Americans, people of Indian descent were not "White" men, and thus not eligible to citizenship.United States v. Bhagat Singh Thind, Certificate From The Circuit Court Of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit., No. 202. Argued 11, 12 January 1923.—Decided 19 February 1923, United States Reports, v. 261, The Supreme Court, October Term, 1922, 204–215. The court conceded that, while Thind was a high caste [[Hindu]] born in the northern [[Punjab region]] and classified by certain scientific authorities as of the Aryan race, he was not "White" since the word Aryan "has to do with linguistic and not necessarily with physical characteristics" and since "the average man knows perfectly well that there are unmistakable and profound differences" between Indians and white Americans. The court also clarified that the decision did not reflect or imply anything related to racial superiority or inferiority, but merely an observable difference.{{cite web|title=Not All Caucasians Are White: The Supreme Court Rejects Citizenship for Asian Indians|url=http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5076/|publisher=History Matters|accessdate=20 August 2013}} At the time, this decision retroactively stripped Indians of citizenship and land rights. The ruling also placated the [[Asiatic Exclusion League]] demands, spurned by growing outrage at the [[Turban Tide and Hindoo Invasion (sic)|Turban Tide / Hindoo Invasion (sic)]] alongside the pre-existing outrage at the [[Yellow Peril]]. As they became classified as non-whites, Indian Americans were banned by [[anti-miscegenation laws]] from marrying white Americans in the states of Arizona, Virginia, South Carolina and Georgia.[http://www.lovingday.org/map.htm Loving Day: Celebrate the Legalization of Interracial Couples] In 1935, Thind relied on his status as a veteran of the United States military during World War I to petition for naturalization through the State of New York under the Nye-Lea Act, which made World War I veterans eligible for naturalization regardless of race. The government objected his latest petition, but Thind was finally granted American citizenship; Yet the Government attempted to revoke it after nearly two decades from his first petition for naturalization.{{cite journal|last1=Coulson|first1=Doug|title=British Imperialism, the Indian Independence Movement, and the Racial Eligibility Provisions of the Naturalization Act: United States v. Thind Revisited|journal=Georgetown Journal of Law & Modern Critical Race Perspectives|date=2015|issue=7|pages=1–42|ssrn=2610266}} In 1946, Congress, beginning to recognize that India would soon be independent, passed a new law that allowed Indians to become citizens and also established an immigration quota for the same. ==U.S. Census== {{further information|Race and ethnicity in the United States Census}} The [[United States Census|U.S. Census Bureau]] has changed over the years its own classification of Indians. In the 1930 and 1940 censuses, "Hindu" was listed as a racial category.Shankar, L.D. & Rajini Srikanth, R. (1998). A Part, Yet Apart: South Asians in Asian America. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. pp. xiv. {{ISBN|1-56639-577-1}}. In 1970, the U.S Census Bureau designated Indian Americans as [[white people|"White"]]. During the 1970s, Indian Americans debated if they should "give up the emotional and psychological advantages of being considered 'Caucasian'" to try to "seek or accept minority status". Indian American groups, through their own petitioning, successfully changed their racial classification from White to Asian in the 1970s to have themselves included in state and federal Asian racial categories to benefit from affirmative action. Specifically, Indian Americans had their official race changed from White to Asian in 1977 "through Statistical Directive 15 of the [[Office of Management and Budget]]", causing Indian Americans to be listed as Asian in the 1980 US Census. Without the action of these Indian American groups, the government would have continued to classify Indian Americans as being White. Since 1980, owing to the diverse nature of South Asians, Indians and other South Asians have been classified according to self-reporting, and have the liberty to identify with the racial and ethnic group that they belong to,Campbell Gibson and Kay Jung, [https://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0076/twps0076.html Historical Census Statistics On Population Totals By Race, 1790 to 1990, and By Hispanic Origin, 1970 to 1990, For Large Cities And Other Urban Places In The United States] Working Paper no. 76 (2005); see footnote 6 in paper with an increasing number identifying as "White", driven by increasing immigration from the North-West of the Indian subcontinent.Morning, Ann (2001). "[http://sociology.fas.nyu.edu/docs/IO/1043/S.Asian.Race.ID.JEMS.January.2001.pdf The Racial Self-Identification of South Asians in the United States]." (PDF). Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies 27 (1): pp. 64 & 75 - 77. {| class="wikitable" |- | colspan="7" scope="col" class="unsortable" align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;"|National Origin and Race |- | colspan="2" rowspan="2"| ||colspan="5" align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;"|Race Selected on 1990 US Census (%) |- |colspan="2"| || colspan="2" align=center style="background: #E9E9E9;"|South Asian|| |- !Nationality||N||White||Black||'Asian Indian' box||Nationality
write-in||Other |- |Indian||2,090||4.3%||2.2%||88.8%||1.2%||3.5% |- |Pakistani||299||6.7%||0.3%||25.8%||65.9%||1.3% |- |Bangladeshi||53||1.9%||0.0%||43.4%||50.9%||3.8% |- |Sri Lankan||38||7.9%||0.0%||26.3%||65.8%||0.0% |- |Total||2,480||4.6%||1.9%||79.3%||11.1%||3.2% |- |colspan="7" align=center|Source: [[IPUMS]] 1990 1% unweighted sample |} ===Self-identification=== Since 1980, owing to the diverse nature of South Asians, Indians and other South Asians have been classified according to self-reporting. In the 1990 US Census, 65% of [[Second-generation immigrants in the United States|second generation]] South Asian Americans identified themselves using a South Asian term, 25% identified themselves as White and 5% identified themselves as Black. In recent years, an increasing number of Indians are identified as [[white people|"White"]] due to increasing immigration from the North-West of the Indian subcontinent, which is home to [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]] ethnic groups within the country. [[Nikki Haley]], the Indian American governor of South Carolina, whose parents are from Punjab in North-West India, identified as [[white people|White]] on her voter registration card in 2001.[https://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2011/07/indian-nikki-haley-says-she-is-white%20 "Indian Nikki Haley Says She Is White"]. ''Mother Jones''. July 29, 2011. Both South Asian Americans and other types of Asian Americans mutually feel that there exists "profound racial difference" between themselves and the other group. Furthermore, "Working-class or state school-educated second generation Indian Americans do not see a natural alliance or unity with other Asian American groups." The 1990 U.S. Census classified write-in responses of "[[Aryan]]" as white even though write-in responses of "[[Indo-Aryans|Indo-Aryan]]" were counted as Asian, and the 1990 US Census classified write-in responses of "''[[Parsi people|Parsi]]''" under [[Iranian American]], who are classified as White along with [[Arab Americans]] and other Middle Eastern Americans.[https://web.archive.org/web/20050313073045/http://www.lib.umich.edu/govdocs/cicdoc/cen90app/ancestry.htm University of Michigan. Census 1990: Ancestry Codes.] at the [[Wayback Machine]] (archived March 13, 2005) Some [[Indian American]]s who were unfamiliar with the [[ethnonym]]ic conventions used in the United States, mistakenly indicated that they were "[[Native American name controversy|American Indian]]" as their race in the 1990 US Census, because they were unaware that this term is used in the United States to refer to [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]]. The Asian American Institute proposed that the 2000 US Census make a new ''Middle Easterner'' racial category and the Punjabi from Pakistan wanted Pakistani Americans to be included in it.Menon, Sridevi. Duke University. "Where is West Asia in Asian America? Asia and the Politics of Space in Asian America." 2004. April 26, 2007. [http://socialtext.dukejournals.org/cgi/reprint/24/1_86/55.pdf] ==See also== *[[Asian American Immigration History]] *[[Indian American]] *[[A.K. Mozumdar]] *[[Race legislation in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Indian-American history]] [[Category:Race in the United States]] [[Category:Asian-American issues]]

revision.comment: Added reference to HOF
revision.text:
'''Robert "Bob" Hersh''' (born February 12, 1940) is a retired American lawyer. He was also the Senior Vice President for the [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF), the world governing body for the [[athletics (sport)|Athletics]], collection of sports known in the United States as including [[track and field]], [[cross country running|cross country]], [[racewalking]] and [[road running]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.iaaf.org/about-iaaf/structure/council |title=IAAF Council |publisher=[[IAAF]] |date=December 6, 2016}}</ref> He was a board member of [[USA Track & Field]] (USATF), the national governing body for the sport.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usatf.org/About/Committees/Board-of-Directors.aspx |title=USATF Board of Directors |publisher=[[USATF]] |date=December 6, 2016}}</ref>
He has held numerous high ranking positions with both organizations that place him at the forefront of the sport. He started with the IAAF on the Technical Committee and as Chairman of the Competition Working Group in 1984. In 1999 he was elevated to the Council and in 2011 was elected Senior Vice President<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/robert-hersh |title=Robert Hersh |publisher=[[IAAF]] |date=July 2, 2002}}</ref> over more recognized retired athletes [[Sebastian Coe]] and [[Sergey Bubka]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.runblogrun.com/2011/08/2011-world-champsdaegu-hersh-al-hamad-coe-bubka-by-alfons-juck-note-by-larry-eder.html |title=2011 World Champs/Daegu: Hersh, Al-Hamad, Coe & Bubka, by Alfons Juck, note by Larry Eder |website=RunBlogRun.com |date=August 25, 2011}}</ref> the two favorites to succeed IAAF President [[Lamine Diack]] at the next election in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/athletics/8719582/Sergey-Bubka-elected-as-IAAF-vice-president-after-controversial-re-vote-at-biennial-Congress.html |title=Sergey Bubka elected as IAAF vice president after controversial re-vote at biennial Congress |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=August 25, 2011}}</ref>
With USATF, he has been a board member since before the organization took on its current name, joining The Athletics Congress board in 1980.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usatf.org/About/Committees/Board-of-Directors.aspx |title=Board of Directors |publisher=[[USA Track & Field]]}}</ref> He formerly served as USATF's General Counsel, and he was formerly the chairman of the USATF Rules committee and the Track and Field Records sub-committee. He is also a member of the [[Association of Track and Field Statisticians]].
With his deep knowledge of the sport, Hersh has been the English language stadium announcer at many high-profile meets including the [[Athletics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Summer Olympics]] through the [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Summer Olympics]] and also the 2004 and 2008 Summer Olympics, the [[IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] from [[1991 World Championships in Athletics|1991]] to [[2007 World Championships in Athletics|2007]], the [[IAAF World Cup]] in [[1994 IAAF World Cup|1994]], [[1998 IAAF World Cup|1998]] and 2006, the [[IAAF World Indoor Championships in Athletics]] in 1987, 1999 and 2008, and the [[IAAF World Junior Championships in Athletics]] in 1994 and 1998.<ref>http://www.usatf.org/News/NACAC-off-the-track.aspx</ref> He was the announcer for the [[1988 United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|1988 Olympic Trials]] when [[Florence Griffith Joyner]] set the world record.<ref>https://www.si.com/vault/1988/07/25/118075/getup-and-go-florence-griffith-joyners-dramatic-garb-made-her-a-colorful-blur-as-she-smashed-the-world-record-in-the-100-at-the-olympic-trials</ref>
He is a graduate of [[Columbia University]], where he was manager of the track and field team<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hepstrack.com/blog/2011/09/04/a-lion-moves-up/ |title=A Lion Moves Up |publisher=HepsTrack.com |date=September 4, 2011}}</ref> and [[Harvard Law School]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theconningtower.blogspot.com/2011/08/hersh-leads-vp-vote-americans-earn-iaaf.html |title=Hersh leads VP vote; Americans earn IAAF committee spots |work=TheConningTower.blogspot.com |date=August 27, 2011}}</ref>
On October 4, 2018, USA Track & Field announced that Hersh was elected into the [[National Track and Field Hall of Fame]].<ref>http://www.usatf.org/News/Olympic-medalists-Dwight-Phillips,-Kathy-Hammond-a.aspx</ref>
==USATF controversy== Hersh's name became the center of controversy in 2014 when the delegates to the USATF National Convention voted overwhelmingly (392 to 70) to retain Hersh as the American representative to the IAAF Council, only to have the Board of Directors reverse that decision in their meeting as the delegates were on their way home, voting 11-1 to select USATF President [[Stephanie Hightower]] to replace Hersh.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trackandfieldnews.com/discussion/showthread.php?144666-USATF-BOD-Ousts-IAAF-Senior-VP-Bob-Hersh-In-Favor-Of-Hightower |title=USATF BOD Ousts IAAF Senior VP Bob Hersh In Favor Of Hightower |website=TrackAndFieldNews.com |date=December 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usatf.org/News/USATF-Board-selects-IAAF-candidates.aspx |title=USATF Board selects IAAF candidates |publisher=USA Track & Field |date=December 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/hightower-645155-iaaf-board.html |title=Reid: Track's Hightower should step up and step aside |work=The Orange County Register |date=December 12, 2014}}</ref> Athlete [[Lauren Fleshman]] said Hightower should step aside, while [[David Torrence (athlete)|David Torrence]] said "It doesn't make sense."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.letsrun.com/news/2014/12/lauren-fleshman-david-torrence-irate-twitter-bob-hersh-stephanie-hightower-usatf-election/ |title=Lauren Fleshman And David Torrence Irate On Twitter Over Bob Hersh / Stephanie Hightower USATF Election |publisher=LetsRun.com |date=December 5, 2014}}</ref> Torrence later switched his affiliation to running for Peru before his untimely death in 2017.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hersh, Robert}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) administrators]] [[Category:American sports announcers]] [[Category:Public address announcers]] [[Category:American sports executives and administrators]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Malay Dilemma
Dilema Melayu {{ms}} | image = The Malay Dilemma front cover.jpg | caption = The front cover of ''The Malay Dilemma: With a New Preface'' | author = [[Mahathir bin Mohamad]] | cover_artist = | country = [[Malaysia]] | language = English | subject = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = Asia Pacific Press | pub_date = 1970 | pages = 188 | isbn = 978-981-204-355-9 | oclc= 246739691 }} '''''The Malay Dilemma''''' is a book written by [[Mahathir bin Mohamad]] in 1970, 11 years before he became [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Malaysia's 4th Prime Minister]]. == History == At the time of publication, Mahathir had just lost his parliamentary seat, been expelled from the ruling party [[UMNO]] and [[Malaysia]] had recently been rocked by the [[ethnic conflict|racial riots]] later known as the [[13 May Incident]]. The book analyses [[Malaysian history]] and [[Politics of Malaysia|politics]] in terms of [[racism]], and posits the following basic positions: * The [[Malay race]] are the [[indigenous people]] (''[[bumiputra]]s'') of Malaysia. * The sole national language is the [[Malay language]] and all other races are to learn it. * The [[Toleration|tolerant]] and non-confrontational nature of the Malays has allowed them to be subjugated in their own land by the other races with the collusion of the [[British Empire|British]]. * A program of [[affirmative action]] is required to correct [[Malaysian Chinese]] [[hegemony]] in business. The dilemma thus, was whether Malays should accept this governmental aid—and Mahathir's position was that they should. Prone to sweeping statements about other races, such as describing [[Jews]] as "hook-nosed", the book entrenched Mahathir's image as a Malay ''[[Ultra (Malaysia)|ultra]]'' (chauvinist). However, Mahathir also dissects the multiple failings of his own race, and the book was intended as a solution leading ''away'' from violence towards a harmonious, [[Racial integration|integrated]] Malaysia (albeit one where [[political]] and [[economic]] power is firmly concentrated in the hands of the Malays). Mahathir was readmitted to UMNO in 1972 and became the Prime Minister in 1981, and in time most of the policies suggested in the book were indeed adopted by the Malaysian government, most notably in the [[Malaysian New Economic Policy]]. The dilemma was revisited in 2000 to 2002 by Mahathir and his successor [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]], who now argued that Malays were well on the way to catching up, and that they should now be weaned away from the "[[Malaysian New Economic Policy|crutches]]" that had allowed them to compete.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} == Criticism == In the preface of the book's first edition, its British publisher casts doubt on the accuracy of Mahathir's assumptions and facts. Mahathir has been criticised for the lack of documentary evidence to buttress his many arguments and conclusions. Bakri Musa states that his assertions and assumptions were based on his personal observations and experiences, with no empirical data to support them. == References == {{reflist|refs= [http://www.adl.org/Anti_semitism/Malaysian_1.asp Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad: On Jews] {{cite book|author=M. Bakri Musa|year=1999|title=The Malay Dilemma Revisited – Race Dynamics in Modern Malaysia|publisher=Merantau Publishers|location=[[Gilroy, California|Gilroy, CA]]}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malay Dilemma, The}} [[Category:Malaysian society]] [[Category:1970 books]] [[Category:Malaysian books]] [[Category:Racial and religious quotas in Malaysia]] [[Category:Malaysian non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about politics of Malaysia]]

{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Udmurts | image = [[Image:Udmurt people.jpg|200px]] | pop = 637,000 (2002) | popplace = [[Udmurtia]] |region1 = {{flag|Russia}} |pop1 = 552,299 (2010) |ref1 = [http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/perepis_itogi1612.htm Официальный сайт Всероссийской переписи населения 2010 года. Информационные материалы об окончательных итогах Всероссийской переписи населения 2010 года] |region2 = {{flag|Ukraine}} |pop2 = 4,712 (2001) |ref2 = [http://2001.ukrcensus.gov.ua/results/nationality_population/nationality_popul1/select_5/?botton=cens_db&box=5.1W&k_t=00&p=100&rz=1_1&rz_b=2_1%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&n_page=5 State statistics committee of Ukraine - National composition of population, 2001 census] (Ukrainian) |region3 = {{flag|Estonia}} |pop3 = 193 (2011) |ref3 = [http://pub.stat.ee/px-web.2001/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=RL0428&ti=RAHVASTIK+RAHVUSE%2C+SOO+JA+ELUKOHA+J%C4RGI%2C+31%2E+DETSEMBER+2011&path=../Database/Rahvaloendus/REL2011/07Rahvastiku_demograafilised_ja_etno_kultuurilised_naitajad/08Rahvus_Emakeel_ja_keelteoskus_Murded/&lang=2 RL0428: Rahvastik rahvuse, soo ja elukoha järgi, 31. detsember 2011] | rels = '''[[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]]'''
([[Russian Orthodox Church]])
and [[Udmurt Vos]]
{{small|Minorities: [[Lutheran]], [[Pentecostal]],http://sreda.org/arena [[Islam]]{{cite book|author1=James Minahan|title=Encyclopedia of the Stateless Nations: S-Z|date=1 Jan 2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313323843|page=1953|edition=illustrated}}}} | langs = [[Udmurt language|Udmurt]], [[Russian language|Russian]] | related = Other [[Uralic peoples|Uralic]] peoples (particularly Permic peoples such as the [[Komi peoples|Komi]]) }} The '''Udmurts''' ({{lang-udm|Удмуртъёс}}, ''Udmurt’jos'') are a people who speak the [[Udmurt language]]. In the course of history, [[Russian language|Russian]]-speakers have referred to them as ''{{transl|ru|Chud Otyatskaya}}'' ({{lang|ru|чудь отяцкая}}), '''Otyaks''', '''Wotyaks''' or '''Votyaks''' (the most-known{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} name). [[Tatar language|Tatar]]-speakers call the Udmurts ''{{lang|tt|Ar}}''.{{cn|date=July 2017}} ==Etymology== The name ''Udmurt'' comes from *''odo-mort'' 'meadow people,' where the first part represents the [[Permic]] root *''od''(''o'') 'meadow, glade, turf, greenery', and the second part ''murt'' means 'person' (cf. [[Komi language|Komi]] ''mort'', [[Mari language|Mari]] ''mari''), probably an early borrowing from an [[Iranian languages|Iranian language]] (such as [[Scythian languages|Scythian]]): *''mertä'' or *''martiya'' 'person, man' (cf. Urdu/Persian ''mard''), which is thought to have been borrowed from the [[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]] term *''maryá-'' 'man', literally 'mortal, one who is bound to die' (< [[Proto-Indo-European|PIE]] *''[[:en:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Indo-European/mer-|mer-]]'' 'to die'), compare [[Old Indic]] ''márya'' ‘young warrior’ and Old Indic ''marut'' ‘chariot warrior’, both connected specifically with horses and chariots.Christopher I. Beckwith. Empires of the Silk Road: A History of Central Eurasia from the Bronze Age to the Present. Princeton: Princeton University Press. 2009. Page 397. This is supported by a document dated 1557, in which the Udmurts are referred to as ''lugovye lyudi'' 'meadow people', alongside the traditional Russian name ''otyaki''.A.G. Ivanov, "Udmurty – 'Lugovye lyudi'", ''Linguistica Uralica'' Vol. 27, No. 3 (1991), pp. 188–92. On the other hand, in the Russian tradition, the name 'meadow people' refers to the inhabitants of the left bank of river in general. Recently, the most relevant is the version of [[Vladimir Napolskikh|V. V. Napolskikh]] and S. K. Belykh. They suppose that ethnonym was borrowed from the Iranian entirely: *''anta-marta'' 'resident of outskirts, border zone' (cf. ''[[Antes people|Antes]]'') → Proto-[[Permic]] *''odə-mort'' → [[Udmurt language|Udmurt]] ''udmurt''.Белых С. К., Напольских В. В. [http://www.udmurt.info/library/belykh/udmetn.htm Этноним ''удмурт'': исчерпаны ли альтернативы?] ''Linguistica Uralica''. T. 30, № 4. Tallinn, 1994. ==Distribution== Most Udmurt people live in [[Udmurtia]]. Small groups live in the neighboring areas of [[Kirov Oblast]] and [[Perm Krai]] of [[Russia]], [[Bashkortostan]], [[Tatarstan]], and [[Mari El]]. The Udmurt population is shrinking; the Russian Census reported 552,299 in 2010, down from the [[Russian Census (2002)|2002 Russian census]] figure of 637,000, in turn down from 746,562 in 1989. [[File:Ареал расселения удмуртов в Волго-Уральском регионе. По данным Всероссийской переписи населения 2010 года..png|thumb|Udmurt resettlement area in the [[Volga-Ural]] region (data based on the National Population Census 2010)]] The 2010 census counted fewer Udmurts than had the 1939 census. ==Culture== {{seealso|Udmurt cuisine}} The [[Udmurt language]] belongs to the [[Uralic languages|Uralic]] family; the Udmurts are therefore considered to be a branch of the [[Finno-Ugric peoples]]. The Udmurts have a national epic called ''[[Dorvyzhy]]''. Their national musical instruments include the ''[[krez (instrument)|krez]]'' zither (similar to the Russian ''[[gusli]]'') and a pipe-like [[wind instrument]] called the ''chipchirghan''.{{cite book|author=Vitaly Michka|title=Inside the New Russia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_IMrAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 June 2012|date=1 October 1994|publisher=SC Publishing|isbn=978-1-885024-17-6}} A chapter in the French ''Description de toutes les nations de l'empire de Russie'' from 1776 is devoted to the description of the Wotyak people.{{cite book|last1=Müller|first1=C. G.|title=Description de toutes les nations de l'empire de Russie | date=1776|location=St. Petersburg|page=65 |url=https://archive.org/stream/descriptiondetou01geor#page/65/mode/1up| language=fr|chapter=Les Wotyaks}} [[James George Frazer]] also mentions a rite performed by the people in his book ''[[The Golden Bough]]''.{{cite book|last=Frazer|first=James George|title=The Golden Bough|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1_guyav82qQC&pg=PA155|year=1913|publisher=Cambridge U. Press|isbn=978-1-108-04738-8|page=155|quote= Annual expulsion of Satan among the Wotyaks of Russia}} Many Udmurt people have [[red hair]][https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/maps-and-graphics/country-with-the-most-redheads-gingers/ Mapped: Which countries have the most redheads?] - The Telegraph[https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-29950844 The people with the reddest hair in the world] - BBC News, and a festival to celebrate the red-haired people is held annually in Izhevsk since 2004.[http://www.izh.ru/i/info/21088.html Рыжий фестиваль - 2017] - Izhevsk city portal ==See also== *[[Mari-Udmurt War]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://udmurtology.narod.ru Udmurtology]—{{link language|ru}}, ''a site devoted to the Udmurt language and online resources''. *[[:udm:|Udmurt language Wikipedia]] {{Uralic peoples}} {{Ethnic groups of Russia}} {{Eastern Christianity footer}} [[Category:Udmurt people| ]] [[Category:Permians]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Russia]] [[Category:History of Ural]] [[Category:History of Udmurtia]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of Russia]] [[Category:People from Udmurtia]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Actors Nakamura Shichisaburô II and Sanogawa Ichimatsu, Toyonobu, 1740s, signed Meijôdô Ishikawa Shûha Toyonobu zu, MFA.jpg|thumb|alt=Woodblock print by Ishikawa Toyonobu of kabuki actors Nakamura Shichisaburō II and Sanogawa Ichimatsu, signed "Meijōdō Ishikawa Shūha Toyonobu zu", 1740s.|Woodblock print by Ishikawa Toyonobu, c. 1740, showing two actors portraying a wakashū (left) and an adult man (right). Note the difference in hairstyle.]]
'''Wakashū''' ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: {{lang|ja|若衆}}, "young person", although never used for girls) is a historical Japanese term indicating an adolescent boy; more specifically, a boy between the ages at which his head was partially shaven (''maegami'') (about 5–10 years of age), at which point a boy exited early childhood and could begin formal education, [[apprenticeship]], or employment outside the home, and the ''[[genpuku]]'' coming of age ceremony (mid-teens through early 20s), which marked the transition to adulthood.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pflugfelder|first=Gregory M.|title=Cartographies of desire: male-male sexuality in Japanese discourse, 1600–1950|publisher=University of California Press|year=1999|pages=33|isbn=0-520-20909-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Leupp|first=Gary P.|title=Male Colors: The Construction of Homosexuality in Tokugawa Japan|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997|pages=125|isbn=0-520-20900-1}}</ref> During this period, the ''wakashū'' wore a distinctive hairstyle, with a small shaved portion at the crown of the head and long forelocks at front and sides, and typically wore [[kimono]] with open sleeves (''wakiake''); boys from wealthier families could wear ''[[furisode]]''. After the coming of age ceremony, the forelocks were shaved off, giving the adult male hairstyle (''[[chonmage]]''), and the boy assumed the adult male style of kimono with rounded sleeves. Although any person would be clearly classified as a child, ''wakashū'' or adult, the timing of both boundaries of the ''wakashū'' period were relatively flexible, giving families and patrons the ability to accommodate the development and circumstances of the individual boy.
The concept of ''wakashū'' contained several partially overlapping elements: an age category between childhood and adulthood; the social role of a pre-adult or adolescent boy, usually conceived of as a subordinate (student, apprentice or protégé); and the idea of the "beautiful youth", a suitable target for homosexual desire and the subject of ''[[Homosexuality in Japan#Ancient and medieval Japan|wakashūdo]]'', "the way of youths". As boys were considered eligible for homosexual liaisons only when they were ''wakashū'', their patrons occasionally delayed their coming of age ceremony beyond socially acceptable limits, leading to legal efforts in 1685 to require all ''wakashū'' to undergo their coming of age ceremony by age 25.<ref>{{cite book|last=Leupp|first=Gary P.|title=Male Colors: The Construction of Homosexuality in Tokugawa Japan|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997|pages=34, note 24|isbn=0-520-20900-1}}</ref>
[[File:Kannazuki, Harunobu Suzuki, c. 1770.jpg|thumb|alt="Kannazuki" (tenth month of the traditional Japanese calendar), polychrome woodblock print. Original woodblock by Harunobu Suzuki c. 1770, later printing. One of a pair (with "Risshun") showing a young couple in autumn and spring, respectively.|A wakashū (seated) and his female companion in elegant autumn surroundings. Note furisode sleeves worn by both. [[Suzuki Harunobu]], [[nishiki-e|polychrome woodblock print]], c. 1770]]
In the [[Meiji era]], the term became obsolete; the first meanings were replaced by the new term ''[[shōnen]]'', and the last by the related construction ''[[bishōnen]]'' ("beautiful boy").<ref>{{cite book|last=Pflugfelder|first=Gregory M.|title=Cartographies of desire: male-male sexuality in Japanese discourse, 1600–1950|publisher=University of California Press|year=1999|pages=221–234|isbn=0-520-20909-5}}</ref>
In [[kabuki]] theatre ''wakashū'' (or ''wakashū-gata'') referred to actors specializing in adolescent male roles (and who were usually ''wakashū'' themselves).<ref>{{cite book|last=Leupp|first=Gary P.|title=Male Colors: The Construction of Homosexuality in Tokugawa Japan|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997|page=90|isbn=0-520-20900-1}}</ref> ''Wakashū'' often also performed as ''[[onnagata]]'' ("woman-role"; female impersonators).
==See also== * [[Shōnen]] * [[Bishōnen]] * [[Shudō]] * [[Homosexuality in Japan]]
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wakashu}} [[Category:Japanese sex terms]] [[Category:History of human sexuality]] [[Category:Shudo]] [[Category:Japanese words and phrases]] [[Category:History of pederasty]]
